Posted: February 18, 2014
												This is not a modern-day type FPS.  No realistic crap, no Call of Duty or Battlefield-type "take cover or die" realism.  This is a BALLS-OUT bad@ss old school FPS.  Did you like (the original) Wolfenstein, Doom, Quake, and Duke Nukem 3D?  If you answered yes to any of these: Buy ths game.  Now.Now to the uninformed, Serious Sam The First Encounter is a FPS bullet hell with swarms of enemies, no cover, but plenty of bombs.  Just collect guns and shoot, shoot, shoot!!!!  The physics are wonderful and the enemies look hideous and hilarious simultaneously.  Plenty of blood and guts, many enemies, and a ton of weapons (I forgot how many, I'm sure the store page says).And don't forget Sam Stone's comments.  I think he was Duke Nukem's cousin.  Maybe nephew.  Maybe both.A+ in my book.  I'm a fan of old school bad@ssery, but if you're not, the game may not be for you.  Go back to Call of Duty, sheep.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Whenever I hear the term "video game" I immediately think of the Serious Sam games. Pure 100% action packed mother♥♥♥♥ing balls to the ♥♥♥♥ing wall holy♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I'm getting my♥♥♥♥♥kicked fun.What is Serious Sam The First Encounter? It's an old-school First Person Shooter, you shoot things, pretty simple stuff, right? Well, the thing about Serious Sam is that it does it so well, all you really need in a game like this is shooting. None of that modern military shooter garbage where it pretends to be "realistic" or "tactical" and it takes itself too seriously. Ironically, Serious Sam doesn't take itself seriously at all, it's fairly ridiculous actually. Non of that two weapon limit crap and health regeneration that seems to be the norm nowadays, this game is seriously bat♥♥♥♥♥♥insane cranked up to eleven.So why is the game so good? It's fun, for one thing. It's you against a horde of enemies, you shoot everything that moves and it's extremely satisfying to do so. You have a wide arsenal of weapons to help you take on the extreme amounts of enemies flying at you constantly. Each weapon is so finely crafted and balanced to suit each situation in the game and you'll learn over time to know what weapon to use when and on what enemies. You can't just stick with the same weapon because you also have to worry about ammo conservation and it might not work as well as other weapons depending on what situation you're in. You'll slowly but surely adapt to the idea of switching weapons constantly and you better, or you'll get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked.The insane variety of weapons you get is ludicrous, and you can carry them all at once. You got your shotguns, minigun, rocket and grenade launchers, laser gun, ♥♥♥♥ING CANNON and more. The game also gives you these weapons at a nice pace as you progress through the game. You'll need every single weapon because this game isn't easy, you will always be attacked by tons of enemies and you'll need to use whatever you have. As for the enemies, there's a very large variety of them as well, and some of the enemy designs are fairly amusing; like headless screaming suicide bombers called "Kamikazes", scorpions with chainguns, reptilian creatures that throw homing balls at you and many more.The level design is nothing more than serviceable, which isn't a bad thing, it does its job, the enemy placement is occasionally very well and the game has nice pacing. You can also look for secrets which are fairly well placed actually, secrets help you out by rewarding your exploration with health and ammo. But what I like about the level design the most is that it isn't the maze-like level design of some other old-school and classic FPSs, THANK GOD (yeah, I'm talking to you, Doom 2!). All I want in a game like this is to shoot the ever living ♥♥♥♥ out of everything that moves and I don't want to spend time figuring out where I'm supposed to go. Occasionally mid-way or at the end of a level you'll be fighting a boss, and these aren't just bosses, they're the size of a building, they're massive and very fun to fight, some of which you will later encounter as regular enemies once you've defeated them.The game also has a storyline, rather forgettable and it's nothing more than a setting for the game but the intro to the game sums it up very nicely. Humankind uncovers some advanced technology from another race, eventually they are attacked by aliens and at the point of being entirely doomed, they send Sam "Serious" Stone, a hero wounded countless times but never defeated, through an artifact called "The Time Lock"; which has the power to send a single person back in time, so Sam is sent thousands of years back in time when humankind had a fighting chance to defeat Mental, the evil bad guy who is responsible for all this mess; and thus Sam fights his way through Mental's horde and whatnot. The Protagonist is likeable and quite awesome though.The game also has multiplayer. STAY FAR AWAY, besides the fact that the multiplayer is dead, deathmatch is so incredibly unbalanced and pointless. There's also co-op, and it's up to 16 players which is kind of awesome but in my opinion, this game shines the most in singleplayer.It's also not a bad looker, while the graphical fidelity isn't incredible, it still has some nice textures and shadow effects, modeling is good but the animations are a bit meh. The game is also very colorful, even though it takes place in Egypt which is always great. Also, the soundtrack is fantastic, it fits the game very well. I also have to mention the excellent sound design in this game. If you listen closely, you can hear the enemies that you are about to encounter and each enemy has its own sound, so you know what to prepare for when you're about to enter a new area or a room. And when you are surrounded by enemies, you'll know which direction they are coming from because you can hear them very well no matter which direction (if you're using headphones, of course).In conclusion, if you're into the golden age of FPS, then you've probably already played this game, if you haven't though; definitely be sure to give it a try. I'd go as far as to say that this is probably the best game to start with for people new to the FPS genre. And as a remake, this is just as good if not better than the original version.

Fast-paced and shamelessly entertaining // Best for those seeking an FPS throwback to simpler times (with better visuals)+ Massive visual improvement over the original game; textures, models, and lighting all have been thrown far into the future compared to the game's original release+ Introduces an autosave function+ Offers cooperative play+ Maps are large and allow for generous movement when in combat+ Enemies attack in droves; spikes the difficulty, certainly, but also keeps the adrenaline flowing+ The action is practically non-stop; there aren't any innovative mechanics by today's standards, but the consistent need for maneuvering and gunplay makes for a great, and a classic, mob shooter+ The monster designes are surprisingly creative, if often campy and odd; here, too, the visuals have been given an overhaul, and the enemies are much more detailed as a result+ There are secrets aplenty, often hidden behind walls+ Applaudable level design+ Weaponry benefits from a moderate variation and a deep satisfaction in their use- With precious little breaking up the fast pace, the gameplay gradually becomes a bit too uniform; can give way to a sense of tedium if played for long hours at a time- Multiplayer appears dead; completely unpopulated, and no active servers at the time of this reviewLockeProposal's Big Day OutCommunity GroupCurator PageSerious Steam Reviews subReddit

content:
Posted: January 25, 2016
Short version: 87%For those who missed the awesomeness of the first Serious Sam games, the HD remake is the perfect spot to jump into this old-school FPS franchise of serious weaponry, hordes of aliens, corny humour, and most importantly: lots and lots of mindless but oh-so-fun action.Long version:After the not so enthusiastic reception of Serious Sam 2, CroTeam decided that it would be better if they returned the franchise to its roots. The result was Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter, which also marked the debut of third Serious Engine. (Apparently they wanted to erase the memory of SS2 so much that they released the remake before Serious Sam 3: BFE was finished.)The finished product is mostly just a facelift on the original game, where the goal is still the same: use shotguns, rockets, cannons, and everything else in the vast arsenal to kill your way through a seemingly never-ending flood of monsters in ancient Egypt, all in order to stop an alien warlord called Mental before he eradicates humanity in the far future. All while finding silly little secrets and listening to the corniest one-liners any action hero ever spoken.There are a few minor tweaks here and there: some new level secrets, rebalanced difficulty (easiest settings don’t reduce enemy health that much), and a few modified enemy spawn compositions or locations. They are not too large to make new players feel they don’t get the original experience, but enough to give something even for the veterans.The graphical update is surprisingly humble. CroTeam touched the levels with respect, only making sure they were up to 2009’s standards, without adding unnecessary effects or any flashy things. This may come off as bad news for those who are used to FPS games being all about grandiose visuals and on-rails gameplay, but great news for those who want to know what makes these games so good but don’t want to go old-school in the graphical department.

Posted: October 9, 2014
												If you're reading this before October 13th, 2014, buy this game now. Easily one of my favorite FPS from the Quake era.  Maybe it has something to do with its large single player maps and it's Ancient Egypt theme. This is a very pretty HD remake and I can't wait to play through it again on modern hardware.  When it was first released in 2001 the whole community was sort of in awe at how such a good looking game (at the time) was priced at only $20...well, at least I was.  While Quake was headed in the Arena direction, Sam stayed true to the single player experience.  Secrets scattered throughout all the levels, hordes of monsters spawning in front of you, and lots of tongue in cheek humor.  This is a classic FPS that shouldn't be ignored, and it will teach you how to circle strafe.

												I remember growing up and playing the original Serious Sam: The First & Second Encounters. They are very good games, especial from an independent gaming company. When I heard that my original favorites were coming back, but with improved graphics, I was happy! The game play is mostly the same, there are a few changes to enemy AI, cut scenes, and weapons, some are good, but some are disappointing. It has the same weapons, enemies, and music and sound effects!Overall, I think the Second Encounter of the HD versions is a better choice, because it contains the First Encounter in it as well, you just don't see the intro, which is a little important if you want to follow the storyline. Serious Sam 3: BFE is the prequel to this series, it tells you what happens before the First and Second Encounters. I recommend this, and the original versions to everyone!

Posted: March 3, 2014
This review is a little lengthy, so if you want a quick summary of why I recommend Serious Sam HD The First Encounter skip to Results and read from there.Croteam makes a smash and they do it without any logic, realism, or sense. The Campaign:Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is an epic game which takes place in Ancient Egypt. This first person shooter is based in the future where the world is about to be destroyed by the monster Mental. All hope is lost until we discover that the way to defeat these monsters can be traced from our past. Further research reveals that humanity has discovered an ancient race the Sirians who had also fought and lost to Mental's might. Humanity finds the ancient Sirian technology known as the Time-Lock which can allow one person to traverse time and space. Our protagonist Sam, who may be very serious, is a champion, a hero, and a legend for humanity. Fighting off every alien he encounters to the end Sam, a true warrior, is given the ultimate task. To use the Time-Lock to travel back in time and to defeat Mental while he is busy dealing with the Sirians. The Gameplay:Serious Sam is revitalized in HD with a stunning thirteen levels (plus an additional two secret levels) digitally remastered and designed to meet the demand of modern day consumers. The graphics are not going to be anything like your blockbuster games, but that’s because the original was produced in 2001 and this is just a remastering. But the game looks rather clean and plays incredibly well. This game not only has secret levels, but is filled with little secrets for the avid gamer. Mysteries abound and things to find Serious Sam leaves you without want. Result:I played Serious Sam: The First Encounter only a little bit when it was released in 2001. Then purchased it recently because it was on sale. Not being an avid fan of the series I can definitely say this game is a fun purchase even if you never really played the original. There are an abundance of crazy enemies, a wacky story (that makes you keep wondering where all the humans are), awesome weapons, fun boss fights, and lots of crazy items. This game not only challenges you in combat making you feel like a hero, but also puts you to the test by throwing puzzles all over the place. The game requires you to solve puzzles, complete challenges, and defeat enemies in order to progress. The levels are long, the campaign is long, the game is a blast, it’s a must buy. If you like puzzles, you like first person shooters, you want nostalgia, or you just like to be a hero then this is the game for you.Pros:+Incredibly fast paced combat+Puzzles in every level+Secret levels and many secrets within each level.+Lots of fun an interesting enemies+An abundance of bosses+Crazy amount of fun weapons to shoot about+Digitally remastered and in 1080p+Fun and gripping story that mixes reality with fantasyCons:-There is a limit to the amount fo auto-saves, you will lose older auto-saves in order for new ones to save, but don't worry you can just continually make saves yourself (I had over 200 by the end of the campaign).-The sensitivity can randomly spark (meaning it just shoots up and your character can suddenly turn with only the slightest mouse movement facing you the wrong way).

Buy this game for yourself and your friends for a better experience, good thing that SS often put to the 90% discount, but actually it worth every penny.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2016
												DISCLAIMER:  I played Serious Sam HD: TFE inside of Serious Sam HD: TSE, so I've logged more time than Steam would suggest.The first two Serious Sam games were pretty novel when they were first released.  As Sam, players ran through massive levels, fighting similarly massive groups of (often massive) enemies.  It wasn't exactly the most radical idea on paper, but it was executed on a  scale that was previously unheard of in FPS games.  Levels often had over a thousand enemies, with fights pitting hundreds of opponents against the player simultaneously; a few enemies were even larger than entire maps in other FPS games.Since then, several of the games Serious Sam has (inevitably) been compared to have caught up to Sam's scope--for instance, there are countless Doom "slaughter" WADs that will throw hundreds or thousands of enemies at you.  But whereas most of Doom's arsenal was never really intended to contend with thousands of enemies, Sam's was built from the ground up with mass extinction in mind, and its bestiary was designed for enormous arena battles.Weapons are your primary means of interacting with the world in an FPS and, in the case of Serious Sam, the arsenal is especially rock solid.  You begin with the typical pistol(s) and combat knife, but it isn't long before you're fielding double-barreled shotguns, miniguns, laser rifles, and even an enormous cannon.  Virtually every firearm fills a niche and will find ample usage--especially on higher difficulties.  Rockets might travel further to snipe distant stationary targets, but the grenade launcher can charge up significantly faster projectiles and shoot around corners; the laser gun doles out tremendous damage up front, but its projectiles take time to travel through the air; the minigun's hitscan shots can mow down faraway crowds, but its ever-so-slight wind-up is a liability in close quarters.  The guns generally feel great to use, as well.  With an appropriate thunderclap, the double-barreled shotgun reduces Kleer to bone fragments; the SBC Cannon's VW Bug-sized shots blast through enemies like so many bowling pins and wipe swathes of the battlefield clean.Enemies are well-designed, too.  Unlike later installments in the Serious Sam series, TFE and TSE don't make the mistake of having numerous hitscan enemies.  Rather, most opponents produce a variety of physical projectiles--some follow you, some scatter, some cut through the air in small volleys, and some lazily fly towards their target--that can be seen and dodged.  That one factor is crucial because it means that dodging can keep you alive even when fighting a hundred foes.  Indeed, Serious Sam almost feels like a sort of "bullethell"-FPS at times, and by encouraging fancy footwork over taking cover, the game maintains a higher degree of momentum than many modern FPS games.  The sheer variety of enemies can be a refreshing change of pace from the standard/heavy/sniper trifecta that so many FPS games like to focus on nowadays.Then there are the levels:  They're huge, and they're especially gorgeous in the HD versions.  While TFE focuses exclusively on an Egyptian-themed mapset, it still includes some beautful setpieces including sprawling palaces, moody moonlit stretches, and Oases.  It certainly doesn't hold a candle to TSE's greater variety, but it does its best.  The maps are packed full of secrets--some obvious and some devious--as well as easter eggs and entire hidden levels.  If you're a completionist, be prepared to spend a lot of time hunting down some of these secrets.Given the size and scale of eveything, one of Serious Sam's biggest selling points is (perhaps unsurprsingly) its co-op support.  Up to 16 players can take on the campaign(s) in TFE and TSE, with a wide variety of player skins to choose from.  You've never really experienced everything a classic FPS has to offer until you're bunnyhopping across massive sand dunes, gunning down waves with half a dozen other players who look like cyborgs, neon cowboys, and Santa Claus.  In fact, there are several different co-op modes including a "Coin-Op Co-Op" arcade-style points/lives system that helps strike a nice balance between players having infinite lives and the level being over for a player the moment they die.  Honestly, I played countless hours of the original TFE and TSE years ago and I still feel that I got my money's worth with the HD remakes.  While they run on earlier versions of the Serious Sam 3 engine than Serious Sam: BFE, they're still perfectly capable of squeezing out some fantastic graphics.  And if you're planning to run TFE HD on an older computer, the sheer number of graphics options will let you tweak everything until it's just right.In conclusion, I'd happily recommend TFE HD to anybody who has enjoyed Serious Sam in the past, who is interested in taking a breather from modern FPS's, or who is simply interested in exploring what is now widely considered a "Classic FPS".

Posted: December 29, 2014
												This Game may not look like much on the outside. Just a grindfest with rooms full of enemies as you trudge from one room to the next. For a long time I thought just that and always avoided this series. On a whim (and recommendations from both totalbiscuit and yahtzee from zero punctuation) I purchased a little game known as painkiller. I loved the gameplay so much I bought Serious Sam HD Gold Edition. I have loved every minute of the serious sam series from its subtle humor to its satisfaction of coming out on top no matter the odds stacked against you. I HIGHLY recommend this game to any fan of first-person shooters or fans of challenging games. This is a true gem of a series and worth full price and more! I loved the series so much I bought a serious sam shirt and every time i typed the work series i almost typed serious. BUY THIS NOW! side note: this game is very difficult.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												Serious Sam First Encounter HD is the remade version of the classical game from 2001, an excellent game with a new skin to keep it ready for a more graphics-wise judgemental audience. Serious Sam First Encounter HD will be a good buy for both new players wondering what the deal is with this thing and why everyone likes it, and the older gamers who remember the originals. It is as true to the original as it can get, with a few improvements.Storywise, it's nothing to write home over. It's a fairly standard story for a game that relies more on its gameplay than on captivating you with word words and more words. Aliens happened, they're after you, you're in acient Egypt and you have guns. Good luck!There is more to it, if you take the time to read into the story there are just enough flavourful blurbs and explanations around that you can read to figure out where your enemies came from, and parts of the storyline, though it isn't something that will carry you through the game, it's more like an extra.The true power of Serious Sam is in the gameplay, with excellent level design, guns that are satisfying to use, and a very high skill ceiling allowing you to feel like a god laying down devastation on hordes of enemies, moving fast enough to dodge almost all of their fire (Since all but a few enemies use projectiles, this means you can dodge nearly everything with enough practice) yet not too fast to become unmanagable. This, along with plentiful secrets, and a game that won't just say 'no' and throw up an invisible wall if you move slighly off the beaten path means that Serious Sam has an excellent grasp the concept of what great games are about- FreedomFreedom to choose your own tactics (And most are valid as well! No need to gimp yourself)Freedom to move as you pleaseFreedom to explore the levels and find all the secretsAnd the freedom to handle any encounter in the way you want to.Along with this, Egypt as pictured is a somewhat unique setting for an FPS game, with a lot of it lending itself for interesting levels and impressive scenery. The enemies you face are unique and mostly iconic as well, with the beheaded bomber and kleer skeleton being some of the more known enemies. In addition, Serious Sam has a great sense of humour, and you can play with a friend, two friends, or a whole army of friends.If you're interested in a great FPS game, this is a game for you.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												The high definition remake of the original Serious Sam: TFE turned out to breathe some serious new life into the game.  One of the original kings of the FPS genre, Serious Sam does a lot of things right, with a few things wrong, and suffers a tad from being a bit of an old title.On the upside, the map sizes in this game are huge, providing a great open-world, fast-paced FPS adventure.  The voice-acting is nicely done with the expected humour and satirical remarks.  The design and layout of the levels are great, and very well-planned and make the game flow very well, but the downside to this game thing, is that if you manage to play for a long stint of time, the game manages to blend it's levels together and it starts to feel a little stale.Nothing about this game is really amazing or innovative compared to todays FPS games, but it does manage to create an atmosphere of non-stop action from start to finish.  There's always something to shoot around every corner, some new tactic to come up with, new enemies to fight and new weapons to pick up.  The old-school secret areas are also a great touch to the game providing secret weapons, armor, health pickups or maybe getting a weapon earlier than you would otherwise.The boss fights are pretty fun and in general the game is still really fun, the added benefit of the HD remaster in graphical fidelity and a few new features (autosave, etc...) really gets Sam back in the game.I would recommend this game to anyone who likes new or old FPS games, just give it a try, you might like it.

content:
Posted: March 4
Review for Solo play :If you still haven't played the nearly masterpiece, in the brutish FPS genre, that is Serious Sam 3, go to play it now and come back here later.So have you loved SS3 ? Then SS1 is worth a deep look. It's in all aspects very noticeably inferior to SS3, but it's still brutish, full of enemy hordes, with a very solid FPS gameplay. It is however less polished and balanced than SS3, and it relies too heavily on quick save & load, which seriously impairs the flow of the game, and can get really annoying at times.Pros :- Very solid & classic FPS gameplay, with very efficient movement & weapon feelings- A lot A ton Hordes Swarms of enemies- Very decent HD remake that brings enough visual quality for my 2010's AAA spoiled eyes- Pretty decent final boss fight...Cons :- ... But lacks of memorable & interesting intermediary boss fights- Gameplay is too much based on quick save & load, as most heavy fights will require to know what monsters spawn from where- Most big fights happen in big open areas that end by all looking similar, meaning there's a lack variety in the battles and we feel we're just doing the same one over & over again- Very few indoor levels, and usually they are annoying because the enemies are designed for outdoor (eg: they are very fast and/or very powerful and thus are very hard to dispose of in close quarters)- Despite the HD remake, too much environment textures are still super low res- 1 "boss" fight seems to have been designed to exploit it as doing it the normal way is supra-hard, while using an obvious exploit (rocket jumping out of the combat zone) makes it ridiculously easyRanting Notes :- The differences between SS1 & SS3 should be taught in game design school. On the paper, these 2 games are very similar, but everything is better crafted, better balanced, more challenging & more enticing in SS3.- As I had played only a little bit SS1 a long time ago, it was funny to discover that most of the bestiary & environment originality of SS3 was already in SS1- Very often when you pick loot, it'll spawn new enemies ; sometimes it works well, ie: it lets you control the spawn speed & order, sometimes it works less well, ie: why do I pick this health potion as I'm going to lose 3 times the HP it gives to me to fight off the spawns ; sometimes it works very very badly, ie: oh, I walked on this because I was running away from too much enemies, and now I'm getting even more enemies ; and it's even worse if you don't notice you just picked up something that triggers additional spawn, coz you're in the middle of another spawning phase >_<- This review has only 1 time the word "serious" or its derivatives... Ok, now it's twice :P

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a remake of Serious Sam: The First Encounter, as you could guess. It was released in 2009 by Croteam and was also known as the first game to use Serious Engine 3. And yep, as serious as ever.It also came out on X360 through Xbox Live service. The only difference that I am aware of is that it had multiplayer only up to 4 players and aim assist.Multiplayer community seems to be dead. Okay, maybe not completely, I did get into some match once at one day. But in other times server list is completely empty. And it makes sense, since Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter has Fusion feature which means that owners of SSHD:TFE get to have Egypt levels to be ported into that game. So instead most of people play in SSHD:TSE.Premise of original Serious Sam is that Sam Stone is sent into past into Egypt to try to stop the Mental forces before they destroy the Earth. And to do this he would need to pass many levels that have sections designed to serve as arenas to lock players inside. You didn't have as much exploration as in Doom or whatever Quake clone game. Instead it was more focused in pacing and tactical choices during combat itself, with encounters lasting few waves, as enemies keep pressuring you to move around. There were a lot of different enemy types and you had a lot of different specialized weapons, so you would have to choose correct gun for each sitatuation, prioritize targets and avoid all the different attacks. It's a classic!HD is surprisingly faithful to the original. I kinda expected it to change a lot of core gameplay, but Croteam is just a honest indie company and gave a game just a nice graphics upgrade. Gameplay is almost same and the awesome soundtrack is completely identical. It's quite nice! And yep, even included Karnak from demo version, just like original. No technology test though.And yea, it looks excellent, with much more natural looking desert and canyons. And if you take a careful look then you will see that some details that was just part of texture is now actual geometry, for example. Though, environment feels not fully finished, as inner places didn't get any additional details and some models seemed to have same textures quality, like statues, despite having more destruction phases. Just good nice new rendering with new light. Though I do wonder about some changes. For example, Alley of Spinxh levels is always at night and the third level of tomb has a fog changed from nice blue color to some dusty brown. As if Egypt doesn't have enough brown color with all sand.But hey, look at all those great shiny weapons. And look at all the remade enemy models, now with ragdolls. Gore and weapons effects just got sexier, as you can now even gib part of enemies bodies, dismembering them, splitting apart, blowing head off with shotgun. It's awesome. Just look at the bull's death, where it would still slide around after being shot, leaving a trail of blood! And heavier enemies now can even be gibbed with a cannon, the heaviest weapon you have. The only strange thing is that Skeleton Kleers and Harpies are always gibbed upon death. For skeletons it looks good. But for harpies it looks strange, even gibs looks like just a few tiny chunks.It also got some nice editing on gameplay. Some beheaded have a saw on their heads, giving them a melee attack. Bomberman looks fancy with that head on a spike, even. And heavy biomechanoids only shoot a single rocket when close to player, to let him have it easier, while it almost always was a certain death being very close to one in original. Kamikazes also seem to have smaller radius of explosion too. Flying gnaars seem to be more dangerous, not stopping when attacking. And weapons switch was made faster, which I approve. Though for some reason you can't walk anymore. Not that it ever was needed, just fancy.If there is one thing I am most thankful the most is that new Netricsa messages notification is put somewhere to the side of a screen and doesn't grab your attention so you can ignore it easily. It was freaking annoying to be visually nagged by it everytime I killed each enemy types while playing custom maps in original.Though, not everything is going perfect and some cuts had to be made. Most noticeably is that some of obscure engine features of Serious Engine 1 weren't implented in Serious Engine 3. Due to this, all the gravity-changing shenagians had to be cut. To be honest, I don't miss them too much, in Serious Sam 1 they were used only as funny thing in a bunch of a secrets, plus once non-secret usage in a secret level. It probably costed more time to reimplent them for something so small. I mean, at least when Croteam was making the first Serious Sam they had plans to make it much bigger game, with futurustic levels which would abuse gravity features. Once they cut it all to be Egypt-only, well, it was pretty much funky leftover.It also doesn't have mirror and sliding surface, which I remember used only once.They also seemed to screw up weapon balance slightly. You see, minigun was made to shoot two times slower, but each bullet does two times damage and is supposed to consume two ammo. But it only consumes one. Result: There is no more reason to use Thompson and you effectively have two times more ammo for minigun than in original. Oh well.But hey, at least Laser gun isn't glitched in HD. It would sometimes start shooting only at half-speed in original. So flaw taken, flaw given.And multiplayer is still awesome. Didn't get to cooperative, but I bet it's same spam, with same cutscene-skipping. And competetive part is awesome, still fast-paced. Although I noticed that rocket-jumping got nerfed and jumping off the slope doesn't give you additional height. But you are supposed to use knife to run fast and it still gets you in many places. And yep, still awesome arena-shooter which proves that you don't need some fancy strafejumping to be balanced and fast-paced.Oh yea, and double shotgun in original was shooting at double speed. In HD it's same as in single-player/coop. Not sure what I think of it, but I think I like it this way. But maybe I need more experience with both ways.Oh yea, and did you know that original The First Encounter was particulary embaressing due to having only a single DM level? Thankfully, HD added a bunch of them, even including Little Trouble from The Second Encounter. Hm, though HD multiplayer doesn't have scorematch mode, only fragmatch. But no one, absolutely no one, was playing scorematch in original anyway, so nah.Overall, not perfect, but damn excellent HD remake with a bit of balance editing, untouched core gameplay, some environment upgrade and great gore system.And yes, those who want to play Egypt levels in Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter have to have this game purchased.

number of helpful: 15 of 26 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 7, 2015
												Synopsis:The classic arcade FPS Serious Sam: The First Encounter, which scored an overall of 87% on Metacritic and was awarded Game of The Year 2001 on Gamespot, is now reborn in glorious high-definition for legions of long-time fans and a whole new generation of gamers around the world. Featuring dazzling visuals and revamped design, gamers take control of the legendary Sam Serious Stone as he is sent back through time to ancient Egypt to battle the overwhelming forces of Notorious Mental and the Sirian army.Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is essentially a remake of the original Serious Sam with a new Graphics Engine. New levels have been added and technically a new weapon, The Grenade Launcher, but this weapon was originally featured in Serious Sam: The Second Encounter.  The Graphics have been enhanced to a certain degree that someone new to the Serious Sam franchise will be able to jump right into it. Basically everything in game received the HD treatment, Weapon texturing and enemy texturing has vastly improved. Sound effects and music are pretty much still the same however.Gameplay is pretty much identical to the original iteration so nothing much has changed. However this comes to the first part that REALLY gets on my nerves with this game. Enemy spawns are damn near AWFUL. I lost count of how many times I died due to a Kamikaze spawning literally right on top of me. Enemy placement sometimes getting downright frustrating at times with for example Kleer Skeletons basically camping doorways and you get double "clawed" from two angles getting heavily damaged if not outright killed from such a attack. "Trap" Enemies are usually the work of lazy map designers. This same trap rule has been applied to ammo and health pickups as well adding on to the sentiment of being punished for picking up items which are supposed to help you.While the game was enjoyable there are many aspects which make it feel cheap and lazy. My recommendation is to either stick with the Original games or get Serious Sam 3.Final Score: 65/100

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												The original game from 2001 is one of my favorite video games, and TFE HD certainly is a worthy remake. The graphics are great and the gameplay is the same simple, fun alien mass murder madness as before. It doesn't have the Serious Editor or Survival Mode (those are both included in TSE HD), but I still definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2016
												I'd recommend that you get this game but I strongly suggest you wait for a sale as it's not good enough in my opinion for a full price buy.Don't get me wrong, it's a fun game. It throws realism out the window for arena styled shooting that has a surprising amount of depth to it (memorizing how many shots to kill an enemy, learning to crowd control, finding secrets, etc.). There's a colorful cast of enemies and a handful of genuinely funny moments. When the cheap rock soundtrack is going and you're dominating the monsters around you, it definitely gets exciting.That said, it is a remake of a fairly old game and the age shows in certain aspects. Sam does seem to try too hard to be funny at times and the writing comes off as flat more often than it is funny. The game's design is pretty solid in most aspects but sometimes it just throws obscene hordes of enemies at you after it runs out of ideas, quickly devolving into frustrating tedium. The guns are also fairly mediocre for a classic fps as some of them tend to be used and handle in very similar ways (the tommy gun/minigun/laser gun are all essentially identical with dps and very slight chagnes in travel time being the only difference).Side note: If your game hangs on the final boss, check to verify cache as the steam client seems to forget to download a 5mb patch.

content:
Posted: June 12, 2013
												After playing Serious Sam 3, I thought I would checkout this game. What can I say? It's actually the follow-on story to Serious Sam 3!! This story starts exactly where 3 left off . Despite it's age, the game is pretty good! Graphics aren’t bad and the gameplay is lots of fun. Since this game came first, you can hardly criticise it for being too similar to Serious Sam 3, but I would definitely play Serious Sam 3 first. Not only will the story make more sense, but you might find those similarities make 3 a little dull. That would be a shame since 3 is definitely the better game. Anyway, this one is well worth the money. It’s an old-school shooter that fast and furious and lots of fun. Buy it!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2016
												No cover, lots of weapons, all man.One of the best frantic FPS just got even better.Not only the graphics are heavily improved, but the fluidity of the action feels a lot better than before.The game has some of the most well balanced difficulty levels I've ever seen; harder difficulties adds in more enemies or changes some to more menacing ones, instead of just tediously upping the damage output and health, which the FPS market likes to do.  It's a lot about quick decisions, rather than pure endurance and conservation, which helps with the afore-mentionned frantic flow of the series.  However, if you're not up for too big of a challenge, there are easier difficulties which makes it so that you're not missing out and right at home.If you're also a junkie for high scores, this game will not disappoint either.

content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												A classic reborn. Serious Sam HD looks as good as the original did when it came out, but with modern graphics and standards. The gameplay is unchanged and as fun as ever.For anybody unfamiliar with Serious Sam, this game is anything but serious. There is pretty much no dialogue and a bare minimum plot. But that's because this is a classic FPS when games involved a character running around with more firepower than an Armored Tank Division. Blast your way through crazy enemies with bullets, lasers, rockets, and...cannon balls. One of the highlights of this game is the massive environment. While some maps are contained to the insides of buildings, lots of the game takes place outside in the deserts of Egypt and the maps are impressive. Not because there's a whole lot to see when running around a desert, but rather there's something majestic and awe inspiring to crest a dune and see a massive, ancient Egyptian city sprawled out before you.This is a run and gun masterpiece and worth every penny.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 4, 2014
												Serious Sam (HD) plays like an old school game. No blood effects on your screen. No slow movement of the character. No gun limits. Secrets everywhere that are varied. No Cut-scenes. Tons of varied enemies. Projectiles you can dodge. Silly blood settings. If you like games where you just kill mindless amounts of monsters while traveling through Egypt I recommend this game. It is a pretty enjoyable experience and a faithful remake of the original without being tainted by influence of modern shooters.Beware though that the servers from what I have seen are pretty much dead, so unless you have 16 people to play with you won't be able to get the full experience of the multi-player in either death match or co-op.

												Best Quick Save Simulator Yet!Serious Sam Is a balls out old school fps and also the remake is one of the best remkes ever.You take on the role of "Serious" Sam Stone, Hes pretty much duke nukem's son, And always has some  great one liners here and ther (Serious Puns). Gameplay, its a old school arena shooter, you go to a big area, and swarms of aliens, zombies and other stuff swarm in to kill you. Youre weapons are standard 90s FPS weapons, Shotgu, Lazer gun, minigun, rocket launcher and other awesome weapons. The canon is awesome, it shoots a giant canon ball that rolls over bad guys, its the "BFG" of the game. now lets talk about the graphics, this is the HD remake and wow, this game looks amazing. everything cranked up and they game looks almost photo-realistic. If i could find i con i really cant, maybe just some cheap moments here and there but in general i really cant. Now this is HARD, seriously (Badoom-tis) you want to punch your monitor sometimes, but after playing throught it 2 or so times, i've gotten good. Over Serious Sam Is Awesome Game, If you dont have a PC that can run this then get "Serious Sam Classics: Revolution" its the original games combined in one game with widescreen support. I reccomend Serious Sam to any FPS fan looking for a challenge.Final Score - 8.5/10

Posted: October 9, 2014
												Best Quick Save Simulator Yet!Serious Sam Is a balls out old school fps and also the remake is one of the best remkes ever.You take on the role of "Serious" Sam Stone, Hes pretty much duke nukem's son, And always has some  great one liners here and ther (Serious Puns). Gameplay, its a old school arena shooter, you go to a big area, and swarms of aliens, zombies and other stuff swarm in to kill you. Youre weapons are standard 90s FPS weapons, Shotgu, Lazer gun, minigun, rocket launcher and other awesome weapons. The canon is awesome, it shoots a giant canon ball that rolls over bad guys, its the "BFG" of the game. now lets talk about the graphics, this is the HD remake and wow, this game looks amazing. everything cranked up and they game looks almost photo-realistic. If i could find i con i really cant, maybe just some cheap moments here and there but in general i really cant. Now this is HARD, seriously (Badoom-tis) you want to punch your monitor sometimes, but after playing throught it 2 or so times, i've gotten good. Over Serious Sam Is Awesome Game, If you dont have a PC that can run this then get "Serious Sam Classics: Revolution" its the original games combined in one game with widescreen support. I reccomend Serious Sam to any FPS fan looking for a challenge.Final Score - 8.5/10

Posted: February 19, 2014
												If you enjoyed the 90s FPS Generation with games like Doom, Duke Nukem 3D, Heretic, Shadow Warrior, Blood and many others others you will enjoy this game. Serious Sam is an old-school First Person Shooter, with all the elements that made classic games great: lots of weapons, no regenerative health, full action without cutscenes and the core: shoot everything that moves.Serious Sam HD is a remake of the 2001 version, with improved graphics, achievements and online features over Steam. I haven't played the original version before and for my surprise I was astonished on how fun this game is. There are several skill option, ranging from the easiest (Tourist) to the most hardcore (Serious). The game can be quite difficult and overpower at some times, and if you enjoy hard games there are plenty of options to make the game even harder than this. And trust me, this game is HARD. I would definitively recommend this game to anyone looking for  some old school action and nice HD graphics.

												Very wonderful remake of the first game that runs extremely well on modern PCs.I wish I had bought this sooner, since I thought "ah, how good could the remake be? I'll just keep playing the original".The remake might as well be a whole new game, but with the same weapons, enemies, maps, etc. Which sounds like an oxymoron, but you would have to play the game to see what I mean.Strongly recommend.

Posted: June 30, 2016
												Well it's exactly as advertised. An HD remake of the first encounter. Unless your computer can't handle it it's the best version of Serious Sam. There's nothing new here, but nothing has been removed either. It's literally the same game as the classic TFE but looks AMAZING. If you don't already have the games the Hd versions are the ones to get (unless like I said your pc can't handle it). If you already own the games there wouldn't be a point in getting these unless you want better visuals(I have all versions of the games on steam because I love them).If you've never played the games before it's basically an FPS where you fight massive groups of enemies in large, open, arenas, shooting, strafing, and jumping like a cracked-out spidermonkey with an unquenchable thirst for mass murder and an warrant for death. You will hear people compare it to quake/ DOOM and while it is closer to that side of the spectrum it doesn't really play like them at all. The ID games were designed more like mazes, while SS has more straightforward level design and is focused solely on combat. Not to say that SS has poor level design (it's quite good!) it's just a different style. The only real issue I could see anyone having with the game is the fact that the entire encounter takes place in Eygpt, but they do a really good job of incorporating variety into the levels, and sure the setting of the game stays the same, all the levels feel different. They are all really well designed and interesting/fun to go through. Some people might also whine about plot development, but I'm pretty sure if your'e playing a game for a narrative you are looking at the wrong form of entertainment. Go read a book. Punk...  Seriously.

												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a very action packed old-school shooter, like Duke Nukem, where the main focus of the game is just to keep shooting with a tough-guy character as the protagonist. I still think this one is one of the best FPS's.There's a storyline, a guide with every monsters you kill/weapons you recieve and lots of secrets. It also has very nice graphics in the HD version and the music is awesome as always. It has a surpringsly long campaign too!I don't know if you'd like this game as a newcomer to the series, but I would give it a try. I'm going to finish both game whenever I have time!Just a little warning though, you will jump off your chair a few times while playing this.

content:
Posted: February 6, 2015
												*jump**shoot**jump**shoot**jump**die**repeat*6/10+Fun system, pleasing to look for secrets and loot+Updated graphics, but still has that old feel. If I didn't know it, I'd say my enemies were flat. (That's a good thing, trust me.)+Runs 60 FPS on every system I've tested on, no matter what the graphics settings were+Lots of customization in settings (Basically, you have the options to change what color/kind of blood you see, and how the atmosphere of the game looks like.)+Database system encourages researching enemies, and quickly identifies the foe you are fightingx Level design, it can be really good at times (Puzzles, mild parkour), but otherwise, it's straight and forward or it's an arenax Lots of difficulty settings, but they feel really poorly designed (I'm playing at normal, and it seems way harder than normal. I've played easy, and it's way too easy. There's at least 6 different difficulty setings. :B)x Saving! You can save, great right! Not really. So, in the game, you can press F6 to quickly save your game. Otherwise, if you die, you are set back to the start of the level. This sucks when you forget to save or are too busy getting blown up to save.x Sound quality. First off, Sam is hilarious. He says some super-generic puns that'd you'd expect from a cheesy action movie or Duke Nukem. But, the enemies sounds... Well, you got the Kamikaze who screams his a** off when he charges, Scorpion bosses sound like someone taking a sh**, and the Bone Horse-thingies are too loud. The game's music isn't that great, but you can't really mute it, because sounds play such an important role in knowing when you're going to be attacked-SUPER REPETITIVE, I kid you not. Combat doesn't change, it just gets harder because the enemies have more health, fire more bullets, or are more plenty in numbers. The combat is basically just jumping and shooting, avoiding enemy charges, or tearing down hoardes.-LEVEL DESIGN! (I know I said this already, but...) There's this one level that was just agony. You start off with your pistols and shotgun (Only the shotgun does good damage) and you have to go into a large field with enemies. Once you kill them all, you have to fight another wave. Then, another wave of harder enemies come. Then , you fight a boss. Then, another boss, and then another, much larger boss. Again, this all takes place in the SAME FIELD.-Plot doesn't justify the game. Why am I fighting? How did I get here? Why are these enemies spawning? Why are there so many? Why do they look the same? What am I looking for? Isn't there a much easier way? What do you mean I have to read about it? It'd be so much easier to explain if it took place in hell.IN CONCLUSION[/b]-Well worth the $1.50 I paid for both of the games-A lot like old games like DOOM or the original Serious Sam-You could probably get much more enjoyment from another game, but this game does have its perks-I'd say it's NOT worth the Steam price (14.99 for the first game, 30.00 for both.)-Good if you're looking for an easy-to-run game to pass the time

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21
												Basic. If you're looking for a shooty game, then this one is for you. This game is a budget one with some touchups, hence the HD in the title. It does it's job well enough. You face a variety of enemies, and have a standard selection of weaponry to take these guys out. If you've played any FPS games from the last 20 years, then these really won't surprise you. Pistols, shotguns, rocket launchers, machine guns, lazer gun, grenade launcher, and this game's crowning achievement: the cannon ball launcher. Its standard now, but maybe back when the game first came out that wasn't the case. At least the monsters you fight look pretty unique and interesting. From bony bovines to the mildly amusing headless suicide bomber, its pretty alright. At the very least it adds personality, which this game doesn't exactly have an abundance of. The hero, sam the serious, is more or less forgettable. Its easy to forget you're playing a character, save for the few moments he says something, which is also unremarkable in execution. Its a strain to talk about the interesting things with this game. Level design is ok. You go through Egyptian styled hallways. Sometimes you might find a secret or a branching path, but it'll always lead back to the hallway. That's integral to the game design, seeing as how more than likely that hallway will lead to a big square chamber; the game's bread and butter. It then proceeds to spawn mobs over and over in waves. This repeats again and again. Sometimes you might have an objective you need to complete, or an item you need to collect, but most of the time will be spent fighting waves of enemies. This game was probably more exciting when it first came out. But now its pretty standard. Most of it is enjoyable shooting fun. There's a rush involved when you're dodging loads of enemies. My main complaint would be the final boss, which betrays the entire rest of the game. Instead of a big huge balls to the wall fight, you get a fight where you run, wait for a door to open, and then circlestrafe until you win. Disappointing, and near impossible in my experience. The final boss needs to be in a specific area of the final map for you to win. The problem is, the final boss only stops to shoot at you. The rest of the time it is moving towards you are relatively the same speed as you move. So, you have a constantly moving boss, in an arena where you need it to be in a specific place. This does not a good final boss make. I ended up cheating to win, and I closed the game and called it a day.It's not bad. But I wouldn't call it exceptionally entertaining either. It's ok.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2013
												Despite several attempts I don't see the pull for this game despite that fact it's very, VERY difficult fps. I swear it's like someone put something like this to try and force competition with everyone. I really don't see any story or why people seem to love this game so much.Update: going back and accepting I don't have the mad (or Serious) reflexes needed for this game I lowered the difficult from Serious and found I had a lot more fun with it and have advanced through many different temple stages, though difficulty still amps up quite high, especially with Kamakazis attacking you!Honestly though, this game is pure gold. I love it's humor, I love how it's never static where creatures spawn. If you try being smart like I try to be, you get attacked by that damn Kamakazis so I suggest headphones or decent speakers as you will need to listen for the "AAAAAHHHHH" before it's too late and you get blown to peices.There are many things to love about this game with it's design and the design of some of the strange otherworldly creatures who see you as an immediate threat and attack you in their own ways, the monster logs making this more fun to learn about these creatures and where they come from.I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to play an old-school FPS. No school like the old school with FPSs imo. Especially on the PC where we've had classics like Doom and Wolfenstein back in the day that invented the genre.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2015
												This game hates you. Once you think an area is clear, the 50th boss fight for that level immediately spawns, and you didn't save. Soon, you will learn to hate it right back. You'll learn what does and doesn't trigger those big swarms of enemies, you'll learn that maybe you shouldn't always look forward, and that maybe you shouldn't always go into secret rooms because then 10,000 monsters will all spawn right on top of you.Despite being a fairly old game, it feels as though it was made just to point and laugh at casuals. There's this one part near the beginning where there's this fairly noticeable shortcut to skip an ENTIRE SECTION of the map if you feel like fighting off a swarm of tough enemies. I would definitely recommend this game for anyone looking for a good FPS game.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2015
												Serious Sam is one of my all-time favorite game franchises. The HD remakes of the First and Second encounters are an excellent way to get into the series if you never played the original from 2001.Diverse enemies, fun weapons, and plenty of one-liners. As a big fan of ancient Egyptian history too, the maps are very cool to run around in. After all these years, I keep coming back because it is one of the few FPS to still give me a satisfying challenge on Serious difficulty. Highly recommended, especially if you can pick it up for cheap during a sale.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Welcome to Ancient Egypt folks.  On your left, a screaming pack of headless kamikazes.  To your right, a green, four armed demon, and behind you, a lava monster.  Meet Sam "Serious" Stone, star of one of the most ridiculous shooters ever made.  With an updated engine, new models, and improved textures, Sam returns to his roots in the first game he ever starred in.  Much like its predecessors: Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem, Serious Sam aims to overwelm you with waves of enemies running straight into your crosshairs.  Explore the secrets of Ancient Egypt with your friends.  Co-op multiplayer is a blast!  If you like mindless killing and simply holding down your left mouse button, this is definitely a game for you!

content:
Posted: February 26, 2012
												Reviewers say the gameplay is identical to the original standard definition edition. They also say the HD graphics really don't add much, and you'll soon get bored of looking at the shiny finish on things. They report it is buggy. Not one glitch/bug did I 'encounter'. The high definition (HD) graphics literally stun. Hours I added to playing time adoring the rich textures and details, and amazing places. Often (after action had stopped,) I would unexpectedly pause in my tracks, and gasp at the visuals. (Woah.)If I still had the original games and played them over lots and recently, maybe then the experience might not work.  However I think I gave my original copies to a charity shop to sell, many years ago. The game was fresher, and more captivating than I ever remember, now sumptuous from HD look. I say it's twice the the game impact of the original, that reviewers say was great. First timers, and veterans of games; try maybe no higher than hard difficulty at first attempt.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2016
												I really wanted to like this game. I thought it would bring some classic, fast paced shooting fun that I haven't had in a while. It did, but it tossed in other things that I'd say ruin the game.(I played on normal difficulty, so my complaints may not be as big of a deal on lower difficulties)Biggest complaint: If you're playing by yourself, be ready to be completely swarmed by enemies, to the point where it's near impossible to get by. There's a part with frogs, where if you don't do the technique just right, you're gonna get pretty screwed pretty quick. Or another part later in that I ran into, where there's hundreds (not kidding) of skeletal things (dogs? maybe?) flooding down a path at you, where you can't really keep the enemy line back, and even if you somehow can, you'll run out of ammo far too soon for it to matter. Can't seem to get around them, either. They'll just crowd around you and kill you in seconds. (came back on this part to find rocket jumping over the spike pit makes it possible, but still irritating.)Other than that, the game can still be cruel in ways it really shouldn't. You found a +1 Health sitting in a corner? We're gonna spawn 5 enemies right behind you when you pick it up. You decided to walk around the whole area instead of just directly going where you have to? We're going to spawn wave after wave of enemy for each little path you go through. It's tedious, and oh so annoying.Then there's just a few nitpicky things, like sometimes with the dual revolvers, the left revolver will shoot 1 more time while the right revolver reloads, then you have to wait for the left revolver to do its whole reload animation before you can shoot again, or some areas you fight in being a bit too tight for the enemies you are fighting in them.tl;dr Solo playing this is fun at first, but is a chore or even a nightmare later in. Probably better with a friend, but who still plays this?

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is an old school shooter set in Acient Egypt, with the protagonist being Serious Sam, a superhuman badass who must go back in time to save Earth from Ugh Zan's invason of monsters! The game itself is amazing, with every minute being filled with non-stop action and shooting. Best part is, there are no objectives. 1 mission for every level: Make it to the end! Now i should note, if you want to start at the very beginning, play Serious Sam 3: BFE first, (BFE = Before first encounter). The achievements in this game are insane, and serious dififculty almost made me ♥♥♥♥ing quit this game. Even on normal this game is tough as nails, but very fun and enjoyable. Another thing i love are the secrets. The secrets are so useful and cool, that even sometimes are surprising because of how much effort are put into 1 mesely secret. Now one of the BEST parts about this game are the enviorments. The grassy and sandy enviroments are so amazing, each level has its own unique enviorment, from sandy egypt-styled enviorments to grassy enviorments, the enivorments are one of my favorite parts about this game! Just look at these enviorments! 


That's a long path... 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002







Secret Level! :D 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002







Dunes 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002




Especialy in the later levels, like Metropolis City. Hell, even the Sewer level didnt fail to give me a damn good level design! There are 13 levels, (15 including the 2 secret levels), and each level is filled with monsters to gib and kill! There are also a lot of puzzles in this game too, mostly levers, pressure pads, etc, but these puzzles give the game a bit more to offer than just killing enemies. The 2 secret levels can be unlocked by doing certain things, but im not telling you how! :3 Now i must say, the game did give me some glitches, not game breaking glitches but otherwise minor glitches that were still noticable. I also thought that sometimes even on Normal that some parts seemed like i was playing on Serious, but then i remembered that this is an old school shooter, and that this is what an old school shooter is all about: Shooting and killing! Overall, Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a blast to play! I highly reccommend it to anyone who loves a great old school shooter!~~~Final Verdict:8.5/10: Amazing!~~~

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is an old school shooter set in Acient Egypt, with the protagonist being Serious Sam, a superhuman badass who must go back in time to save Earth from Ugh Zan's invason of monsters! The game itself is amazing, with every minute being filled with non-stop action and shooting. Best part is, there are no objectives. 1 mission for every level: Make it to the end! Now i should note, if you want to start at the very beginning, play Serious Sam 3: BFE first, (BFE = Before first encounter). The achievements in this game are insane, and serious dififculty almost made me ♥♥♥♥ing quit this game. Even on normal this game is tough as nails, but very fun and enjoyable. Another thing i love are the secrets. The secrets are so useful and cool, that even sometimes are surprising because of how much effort are put into 1 mesely secret. Now one of the BEST parts about this game are the enviorments. The grassy and sandy enviroments are so amazing, each level has its own unique enviorment, from sandy egypt-styled enviorments to grassy enviorments, the enivorments are one of my favorite parts about this game! Just look at these enviorments! 


That's a long path... 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002







Secret Level! :D 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002







Dunes 
A Screenshot of Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter
By: soniclives2002




Especialy in the later levels, like Metropolis City. Hell, even the Sewer level didnt fail to give me a damn good level design! There are 13 levels, (15 including the 2 secret levels), and each level is filled with monsters to gib and kill! There are also a lot of puzzles in this game too, mostly levers, pressure pads, etc, but these puzzles give the game a bit more to offer than just killing enemies. The 2 secret levels can be unlocked by doing certain things, but im not telling you how! :3 Now i must say, the game did give me some glitches, not game breaking glitches but otherwise minor glitches that were still noticable. I also thought that sometimes even on Normal that some parts seemed like i was playing on Serious, but then i remembered that this is an old school shooter, and that this is what an old school shooter is all about: Shooting and killing! Overall, Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a blast to play! I highly reccommend it to anyone who loves a great old school shooter!~~~Final Verdict:8.5/10: Amazing!~~~

content:
Posted: September 28, 2016
												Worth buying if you get it on sale and playing for a few hours until the fun starts to wear off.Otherwise:• it's an 90s style FPS, like DOOM 1&2 or Painkiller• good antidote to overcomplicated puzzle games• you'll get bored of staring at indistinguishable Egyptian temples about an hour in; it goes on for a lot longer than that• level design over-relies on some "cheap" feeling gimmicks like teleporting monsters into the world behind you• levels feature prominent, genuinely funny booby-traps• has working, non-mandatory co-op multiplayer• one technical flaw with the audio: no HRTF. You can't locate sounds by ear very well because the way the game simulates sound isn't detailed enough (it doesn't simulate phase differences caused by sounds arriving at your ears at slightly different times, which is the most accurate mechanism your brain has for working out which direction a sound is coming from)• some of the monster designs are bad, by which I mean tedious to fight (stupid undead bullet-spongy ponies)• occasionally the game throws one or two hundred of its most boring monsters at you (ugh so many ponies)• some of the weapon designs are crap, by which I mean they hit like wiffle bats and that's just boring• unfortunately, all the voice acting and the sounds… sound like they're from a 90s FPS. Ew.

												I refunded this game. Before you continue reading, please know that I am a professional video game critic.The problem with this game is not really that it is a bad game. The problem is that there are better games with the formula that this game uses. The level design isn't good, and that is why killing enemies feels like a chore after a while. The guns don't feel that good either. Why do I recommend this game if I am writing negative you may ask? That is because most people might not have played Quake 2, DOOM or Shadow Warrior.If you haven't played the above mentioned titles, I think you will have a good time with this game.

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												First of all i love old school  fps games. So this isn't about the game's age. Problem is this game failed as a shoot'em up, because of shooting feel. It feels  exactly like virtua cop 2 (gamer dinosaurs unite!) which is a very bad thing about fps games(not for arcade games). Just click and shoot, you can't feel any thing (hit or being hit). Like shooting clouds. By the way, I can speak about other annoying things like spawning enemies, similar levels etc. But i don't, cause it's useless. Everything about single player is coming short. And i think the devs probably know that, cause above the %80 achievements are about multiplayer deatmatches. And guess what, multiplayer is dead. Surprise(?) i don't think so. Well for the final i can say, if you like this game (or nostalgia) and have friends like yourself, you can buy it (on sale of course).  Otherwise i don't recommed it, even on sale. Especially new players, look for other games friends, this game was all about hype and hype was dead long ago.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2016
												Well, i played this games (Serious Sam I and Serious Sam II) in my adolescence and it brings me memories.That would be the main reason which i bought it for, however, as a gamer for about 15 years by now, i would say that Serious Sam is a fun-to-play-with-lot-of-friends game but only if they can argue and chat by voice so you can hear them complain about the flaws, bugs and hateful mobs.I haven't play it in single player, but i forsee its going to be a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ as mobs spawn too much and the game itself is boring. You only have to kill, you can't level up, there is no sense of rewarded-challenge- The difficulty level increases as more and more mobs appear in specifically hard spots where, to aim, you have to ignore all the melee attackers and guess what? melee will continue spawning until you kill those big mobs far away.Its a thumbs up what they did with the graphics, but it sucks that mods usage doesnt count for challenges, for example, What would be the problem with my steam badges if i choose to play as a Patrick Star (SpongeBob friend) character?In conclusion:-Play only with friends with microphone-Dont rush-Dont play the whole game in one stand (is even more boring)-Buy only if you like shooters-Its very repetitive, and gets harder each 100 meters you walk-You are going to die a lot of times-You are going to curse some challengesWould i recommend it?Only if you have lots of friends with microphone playing it at the same time AND/OR if you played it as a kid and you plan to play it again.

content:
Posted: February 16, 2015
NOTE: This game is FUN HOWEVER, I just don't recomend it to people like me, who are looking for a frantic single player experiance. Dang I wish Steam had a "MEH" buttonIs this game bad? NOIs this game great? NOIs this game heavily flawed? YESDo I recomend it? Eh... I am going to have to go with "NO"Welcome to the world of Serious Sam, a strange world where you goal is to kill anything that moves. Sound fun? It is! A ton of unique diverse levels for your crazy brain to plow through. Tons of enemies and great satisfying levels make for what should be a phenomenal game! Why isn't it then? Simply put the levels have some of the worst design choices I have ever seen in any game I have ever played. Sure some points the levels can be a blast, like the first half of City of Memphis - Metropolis where you have to go around a city styled maze and collect the 4 scarabs while avoiding the waves upon waves of different enemies that are searching for you in the maze, and City of Memphis - Sewers with some original designs and very generous enemy placements which make for a unique intense experience. However, 2 MAJOR flaws bring what should be a great game quickly down to some of my least favorite games of all time.First MAJOR FLAW: Unfair Padding/ Poor Level Design:Red signs of these problems start to appear however once you start playing the second half of the level City of Memphis - Metropolis, there is a pit with spikes with a chaingun that is supposed to spawn across from it to signify that you should go over there, although the first time I did it, it didn't spawn. A bull comes barreling across the pit and of course in classic game fashion it saves right as it is about to hit you giving you exactly 1 second to respond once you load up the save which is a whole different can of worms. Once you cross the pit you hear more bulls, a few dozen come flying at you and it shouldn't be a problem until those freaking skeleton running things come running at you and guess what... there are well over 100 of them. Earlier I did say how waves and waves can be fun... but only in well designed arenas like the one previously mentioned. However at this part it is just a straight hallway leading to a double door where they are spawning.They even continue to spawn even when you get on top of their spawn point making them practically impossible without rare or even unfair luck. Prior to this the level Oasis is entirely padding. From the first part of the level with the outside madness of hundreds to enemies to the "boss encounter". Why is it in quotes? Because, frogs... They decided that whenever creating a game, if you want to pad a level over 8 minutes without putting in any effort is spawn hundreds of small enemies that kill you easily inside a small square room. GENIOUS! It's not that I am against difficult games, because I am not (just look at my achievement list that includes Cave Story + Blood Stained Sanctuary which is one of the HARDEST levels in video game history). This happens more than once throughout each levels, some more then others which makes the game very hard to enjoy. From what it seems, they took a lot of time designed the first part of a level (excluding everything in Oasis) and then just decided "Man I took way to long on that level and it's not even up to the adverage length! Lets spawn 1000000 enemies!" which is most unfortinute.Second MAJOR FLAW: Enemy SpawningAs I stated above briefly whenever you get near where an enemy spawns it does regardless, making for a practically instant death. An example is in Oasis in the first room you have the ability  to grab health on the edge of the valley. Once you get over there, enemies have the ability to spawn and can spawn directly on top of you which lead you directly to death. This happens a lot of the time in the game and really bogs down the experience.ConclusionAnd those are my main problems with the game. Does it make it terrible? No. Does it make it unenjoyable in every sense of the word? Yes. Unfortunately what Croteam fails to see is that when designing a level one should design it well and not but one hallway with a few hundred of the same enemies spammed to be sure to kill you artificially lengthening the level, and expecting a player to know where an enemy spawns before it spawns which leads to an almost instant death is just cruel. I did finish the Demo Level on Hard difficulty and I had a blast. But I played on the 5th level of this game on Normal and I felt like I was being killed just for the sake of padding. Again, NORMAL what most people start playing a game on. Overall I recommend this game for friends. But as it stands this is one of the most unenjoyable single player experiences on Steam.Pros:+ Fantastic graphical style+ Fun setting and level styles+ Fun and uniquely satisfying weapons+ Fun and diverse enemies+ Fantastic MultiplayerCons:+ Absolutely atrocious level design+ Abysmal enemy spawning mechanic+ Very Very Poor singleplayer experience leading to no fun at all.Overall: 5.8/10 "Major flaws that bring what should be a great game down low"

												First part of the game is pretty good, with interesting level layouts and beautiful visuals.The real problem with this game lays in the latter half of the game within the final 2-3 levels. Each enemy encounter becomes a MASSIVE grind fest killing the same 2-3 enemies over and over in giant waves within the same looking giant box. Over-all, it isn't a terrible game. The first part of the game is fun, but latter half is incredibly boring.However, if you're considering buying this; skip it. Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter has this games campaign included in it. Save your money by buying THAT one instead. I would not recommend buying this based on that fact alone.And please note that is the ONLY reason I do not recommend this.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2016
												I know what people will say. "Git gud" or "this is an FPS for REAL hardcore gamers". This game is just plain old unfair. It's not like other classic FPS games that give you a challenge that is satisfying when you overcome it. This one just kicks you in the balls on a constant basis. What happens in DOOM when you find a secret room? You get a ton of health, armor or ammo and you feel like you made a small little accomplishment. You get rewarded for your effort. What happens in Serious Sam when you find a secret? You get an item that gives you 1 HP and spawns a mass amount of enemies right behind you that will take off 40 HP from you in a second. Why the hell would I wanna seek out secrets if your gonna punish me?The enemies also have a really annoying spawn system. Walked into a new corner of the map? Spawn enemies. Grabbed an item? Spawn enemies. It's so constant and they spawn all around you. You're often unfairly ambushed.Obviously this is the point of the game. To be punishing. But guess what? If there's no sense of accomplishment at some point, there's no reason to play it. Dark Souls makes me feel really good in between making me rage. This game doesn't in the least. I haven't beat it yet (got to the mass stampede of those skeletons and bulls right after you get the minigun) but I can't play it for more than 15 - 20 minutes without taking a break. It's so damn monotonous.Yeah, it's a classic to many, and I won't say you're wrong for loving it, but to me Serious Sam is the worst of the classic, challenging FPS games like DOOM, Duke Nukem and Quake.

content:
Posted: January 14
												An "HD" remake of the original Serious Sam but without any real improvements. The graphics might be higher rez but the models & environments are chunky and texture work is unimpressive. Gameplay is way too finicky and reminds me Duke Nukem where each level has to be played perfectly just to survive. The main reasons I liked Quake & DOOM was because of the great sense of speed and freedom of movement. Meanwhile, SS takes the complete opposite approach with you crawling through levels and spending the majority of the game backpedaling while holding down M1. Tedious gameplay, bland graphics and sound, and boring map & game design round out this unnecessary "remake". Nothing new or noteworthy here and not worth picking up for anyone. 5\10
