number of helpful: 4 of 19 people (21%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 3, 2016
												The voice acting is pretty good, it's quirky and even inspiring sometimes- though more often than not cliché and watered down in to one liners.The gameplay is essentially Doom 2 with a few new enemy behaviors and more rooms to be locked in until you clear them out entirely of said enemies and much longer and larger levels.If you think finding secrets and exploring levels is going to benefit you in any way, think again. Exploration and finding secrets is punished abrasively as an artificial difficulty increase. You might get some bonus health, or extra armor, or a new weapon a little early compared to finding it on the beaten path you're seemingly expected to rush through, but you wind up being ambushed by enemies that will more than likely make the collected secret not worth grabbing.The sound design leaves a lot to your imagination and even more to be desired. You can often hear enemies before you see them, usually you'll hear ones hiding in ambush of you going to secret chambers and stuff, which is sort of a way to know where not to go though it's not always useful since the orientation of where sounds are coming from is not properly given to the player regardless of how you have your audio set up. (Even on a 5.1 you can't audibly tell where an enemy who's ahead and to the left of you is without it being in your direct field of view) which makes for some more awesome "ambushes" from enemies that are around corners and behind walls from you.The "intense mood music", which plays only when enemies are actively pursuing you, became annoying not even 3 minutes in to semi-active combat.Overall this game is not ground breaking, it'd be better named as "Frantic Frank". Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is bold irony and a step back as far as FPS titles are concerned.If you want to play something similar but actually good check out Rise of the Triad.

number of helpful: 4 of 20 people (20%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 17, 2011
												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a very direct remake of the 2001 sleeper hit it is based on. To summarise, the game's an arcade focused FPS where you success is driven by fast reflexes and ability to chain points. Besides some glossy modern day improvements cosmetically including: a new physics engine, gore, some destructable environments and DX9c quality visuals, this edition is no different now as it was nearly ten years ago from release. It's fairly upsetting, and actually the game's flow still never manages to be as fluid or smooth as I remembered from all those years ago. Perhaps Serious Sam HD's biggest fault lies in that it hasn't taken advantage of any major gameplay improvements made in it's sequels, like Serious Sam: The Next Encounter on Gamecube even. The presentation is fairly average with below average menu navigation and poor multiplayer lobby support. It's an easy game to run, and supports the Xbox 360 controller but this release is tough to endorse otherwise.

number of helpful: 18 of 52 people (35%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 22, 2016
												Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is remastered version of a rather old game from 2001. Back then it got good reviews and earned popularity among pc gamers. But how does it hold up today?Pros:   Graphically the game looks beautiful and highly detailed for an old game remaster. Physics feels good and makes killing so much fun.  Core gameplay is good and twitchy shooting is at least fun at the start of the game.Neutral:  Multiplayer is really chaotic and unstable, but at the same time it’s worth to try. Unfortunately it’s hard to find a single match nowadays. Not enough boss fights. There are only a few gigantic bosses, but I wonder why devs didn’t make some more? Cons:  It’s absolutely the most repetitive game I have ever played. Same enemies, patterns, areas get so boring after a few hours.  There is some kind of a story about getting back to ancient times. However, it presented in a really poor way - dull looking text between missions. Oh, and fonts are small too to make player suffer even more. Glitchy achievements.  Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a good remaster, but a very average game at it’s core, due to repetitiveness and lack of more interesting features.6.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 17 people (12%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 5, 2013
												Serious Sam, huh? More like Serious♥♥♥♥♥♥ That's all this game is. One big♥♥♥♥♥♥ A steamy pile of doo doo.Serious Sam at its core is a mindless run and gun with no heart or soul. The main character tries so hard to be Duke Nukem for no apparent raisen. Sam himself is an idiot amongst idiots. Every enemy you fight is just a faceless thing throwing itself at you in waves. The developers must have been really confused with character design for the enemies. They just toss in whatever random crap they can think of. From what little story there is, most of the enemies don't really fit the genre of the type of enemy you're supposed to be up against. Which is aliens, I guess... but most of the time you fight weirdo♥♥♥♥♥♥like feral screaming idiots without heads trying to suicide bomb you. There's a scorpion man with a machine gun attached to his arm... some sort of flying harpy... a skeletal demon thing.. the stupid bull creature from Star Wars Episode II... Oh, and the final boss is Satan. Anyway, the story makes little to no sense at the best of times. The egypt setting is kind of cool, but little is known as to why it takes place in egypt... I know it's an older game and I shouldn't be so hard on it. But ♥♥♥♥ this game, I've played games way older then this and most of them  haven't been nearly as ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ as this thing.I'll give the HD version of this credit for actually looking decent with a nifty engine. But what good is any of that junk when the game itself is poo poo labanza? Final Verdict (1.1 out of 5) - and that's me being generous.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												This game tries to evoke the exciting, arcade-like feel of early-generation first person shooters like Doom.  However, when making this game, the creators didn't notice that a lot of what made Doom and the early Quake games fun was tight controls, satisfying weapons, and an atmosphere that took itself seriously.  Serious Sam has none of those, so it feels like a half-baked mod with a bunch of silly concepts.

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												Awful HD remakes. Lag-stuttery performance because of either poor coding, poor optimization, or both. This game has one area, egypt, and the second encounter is the exact same game with egypt in it but also a few more areas, so I basically got ripped off and did not need to buy the first encounter because it is useless. $2.50 wasted. Only a cult set of people enjoyed these turds back when they came out long ago and nowadays nobody really cares about them and for good reason. Giant, open, lifeless, contentless, boring, repeating, ugly, lonely levels are each entirely the same color (tan or green or whatever) with a few props and of course thousands of boring enemies with poor shooting mechanics from seemingly 1992. It is too bad the cool art direction of the enemies could not have been used for a better game because a few of the enemies are pretty cool.Take Doom, Quake, and Half-Life, take away every single thing that made them all so great, and you have this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ garbage of a game. One of the most generic, watered down fps games I've ever seen. It is not fun.The weird thing is that the only decent game out of them all is Serious Sam 2 and Serious Sam DD XXL. Serious Sam 3 is one of the worst games of all time.

Posted: July 30, 2012
												After realizing within a couple of levels of MW3 that I'm all CoD'ed out, and after enjoying the shootfest of Bulletstorm, I decided to go back to my roots and try some plotless twitch shooting. Well now. It turns out that I need something slightly more than pure plotless twitch shooting; although this was mostly fun as hell and a definite boon for my twitch-aiming, some of the levels were stupidly difficult or just over-long, the boss fights were dull circle-strafes, and it basically outstayed its welcome. Still, what do you expect from the design for a game this old? It was OK. And thanks to the Steam sale I have all the sequels to play, too. Hmmm...!

Posted: December 5, 2012
												If you're looking for a game with a solid storyline, realistic gameplay, strategic cover, regenerating health, 6 different assualt rifles, 4 pistols, and a handful of submachine guns, all with fancy scopes and stuff that you don't need, then you're in the wrong place. Play Serious Sam, and take a trip back to the golden age of shooters, where violence is fun again. Get rewarded for exploring the map, not killed for "going AWOL". Find new guns earlier, and extra health and armor. How about a cannon that splats any enemy it shoots, or a 4-barreled laser gun? A double shotgun that does as much damage as a rocket launcher? Fight giant scorpions with chainguns, and 100-foot lava golems. And did I mention the headless kamikazes? This game is a SERIOUSLY fun time.

Posted: October 3, 2011
												Like the best pieces of software out there, Serious Sam does one thing, and does it extremely well: Pit you against impossible numbers of suicidal enemies. But don't be fooled; your foes, though seemingly lacking both beauty and wisdom, are still capable of advanced and cunning tactics. Among those are spawning behind your back or right in your face, remaining immobile indefinitely in a shadowy corner waiting for you to walk into the room, or - when all else fails - running directly into gunfire in hopes that your supplies will vanish sooner than their ranks. Which will often prove a remarkably effective strategy.

Posted: February 23, 2014
												If you want an arcade style;  start A kill X goto B Kill Y goto C kill Z type of game, this may suit you.I typically want some more motivation in a character, and I joked to friends, silent protagonists in other games have more character than "Sam". There arent alot of mob types,  but the game occasionally will put a hundred mobs on screen and it doesnt drop in FPS at all, which I found to be pretty impressive. There is an online compoent Ive tried several times to use, but it seems few, if any use it. Steam reviews need a meh button. As far as Im concerned, im just not the target audience, its technically sound, the environments are nice, the music is good. The gunplay is amusing.  "Sam" just is lacking to me. I cant hate on a game thats not really aimed at someone who frequents RPGs and the like.

Posted: July 12, 2011
												Serious Sam: First Encounter, published and made by Croteam (from Croatia) was a very awesome, arcade first-person shooter where you can blast off monsters rather than a storyline like the likes of Half-Life series. But, not only you can blast off monsters in it, but it contains some puzzle that you kinda solve for yourself. Thankfully there are hints to know where they are and you just wen through it.The monsters are a bit cheesy but there are some that are hilarious, especially with those kamikaze bombers, whose are headless and come and say "AAAAHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH" and it explodes you up. Creepers from Minecraft won't touch that one.Despite the fact it is made by Croteam, I can honestly say that this game was good. I've haven't seen any international game publishers who can sucessfully made a good game out of it (though Japan makes ALOT of good games and some bad games). Thankfully there are no lolis and pedobears  in this game. LOL!Overall, good game! :)

Posted: March 24, 2012
												Shoot, shoot, shoot and shoot some more. That's Serious Sam for you. When it first came out it was something out of the ordinary. With a surprising success. Wandering through levels with some nice looking old egyptian architecture, you fight armys of monsters. This time, the word "army" is to be taken seriously, as you literally kill thousands of monsters from start to finish. A few simply "collect item" and "push switch" puzzles in between give some variety, but the big picture is just you, your gun and what you can shoot with it: EVERYTHING!Sam himself is more or less a cheap copy of Duke Nukem, with a similiar rough voice (though not as cool sounding) and one liners, as well as some comedic relief and a few references to pop-culture. The HD Version really enhances the graphics, in direct comparison to the standard version. Give it a try for some mindless action, even with co-op!

												It's a very specific kind of shooter, comparable to Painkiller. There are many who, being used to different styles of shooters, will dislike this kind, at least at first. Posted: September 17, 2015
												No aim down sight, no cover based shooting and absolutely no nonsense.This is shooters as shooters are supposed to be, harkening back to the days of Doom, Quake and the many ripoffs those games spawned Serious Sam is a bit of a ripoff itself of thse classic games and doens't revolutionize the forumula but it does take it's own unique place upon it, it's skill based with hundereds of enemies you have to fight all at once and of course it's legendary coop. A 'cult classic' if there ever was one, if you like oldschool shooters you owe it to yourself to at least give this game a try.Do yourself a favour and grab some friends, crank the enemy health up as high as it can go and have a blast getting your asses kicked, the crazy frantic action of the coop is what this game is most famous for but the singleplayer is still a wonderful challenge.Prepare to backpeddle and scrap for every bit of health you can.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												This is a 100% accurate to the original HD remake of a fully old school shooter from 2001.Since this is an old school shooter the story matters the least and is almost non-existent, but the story is earth is struggling to beat this evil alien race and earth sends this guy Sam serious Stone to go back in time to ancient Egypt to kill all of them, nothing in this game is meant to be taken seriously.The gameplay is your typical old school shooter where you’ll go through levels from point A to B and killing everything along the way, though serious Sam is quite unique among old school shooters since you move through really large open environments, you’ll have hundreds of enemies charging at you all at once, most items are booby trapped and enemies will spawn when you pick up certain items, and you have Sam stone who is very similar to duke nukem where he spits out one liners and steals movie quotes. You have a set of weapons which consists of a knife, dual revolvers, a shotgun, a double barrelled shotgun, a Thompson, a mini-gun, a rocket launcher, a grenade launcher, a laser gun, and a cannon which is like a cannon of a ship but it fires cannon balls the size of boulders which will run over anything smaller than it and explode within contact of anything larger than it. Certain weapons work better on certain enemies and different situations since a lot of the time when there is a horde of enemies charging at you, you’ll be using the rocket launcher but when you are in too tight quarters for the rocket launcher and enemies are too close to you, you’ll want to switch to the mini-gun, and when there’s not that many enemies you might want to switch to one of the two shotguns. There aren’t really any problems with serious sam but this game is very frustrating especially on the higher difficulties because this game is extremely difficult and it has some of the most annoying enemies in any game ever made and when you have a 100 of them bee lining towards you it’s just overwhelming. There’s also this one point early on in the game where the difficulty spikes completely, but none of this stopped me because I finished this, the second encounter and 3 all on serious mode. This is one of the best old school shooters ever made and you should definitely get this if you like old school shooters.

Posted: September 17, 2015
												No aim down sight, no cover based shooting and absolutely no nonsense.This is shooters as shooters are supposed to be, harkening back to the days of Doom, Quake and the many ripoffs those games spawned Serious Sam is a bit of a ripoff itself of thse classic games and doens't revolutionize the forumula but it does take it's own unique place upon it, it's skill based with hundereds of enemies you have to fight all at once and of course it's legendary coop. A 'cult classic' if there ever was one, if you like oldschool shooters you owe it to yourself to at least give this game a try.Do yourself a favour and grab some friends, crank the enemy health up as high as it can go and have a blast getting your asses kicked, the crazy frantic action of the coop is what this game is most famous for but the singleplayer is still a wonderful challenge.Prepare to backpeddle and scrap for every bit of health you can.

Posted: September 13, 2012
												Don't know which murder simulator to buy, and haven't played Serious Sam HD yet? I think I can make your decision a little easier. Short version is, get Serious Sam HD: TFE. Long version is, get Serious Sam HD: TFE, maggot. Better yet, get the TFE/TSE bundle. TFE is a game about Sam "Serious" Stone killing massive loads of alien creatures in ancient Egypt armed only with his wits. As well as a cannon, a chaingun, a rocket launcher, a grenade launcher, a laser gun, a tommy gun, a big knife, two shotguns, akimbo Colt .45s, and a neurally-implanted computer system. Because he didn't want to overdo it, you see. Logically, I can assume that this has already convinced you. Thus, I'll leave you with this advice: set your color options to "Vivid". Trust me on this. If the default colors are pretty, then Vivid is BEAUTIFUL. Now get out there and tear a Werebull a new one. ...Oh, and do tread lightly. Sometimes that +1 HP just isn't worth it.

Posted: December 5, 2012
												If you're looking for a game with a solid storyline, realistic gameplay, strategic cover, regenerating health, 6 different assualt rifles, 4 pistols, and a handful of submachine guns, all with fancy scopes and stuff that you don't need, then you're in the wrong place. Play Serious Sam, and take a trip back to the golden age of shooters, where violence is fun again. Get rewarded for exploring the map, not killed for "going AWOL". Find new guns earlier, and extra health and armor. How about a cannon that splats any enemy it shoots, or a 4-barreled laser gun? A double shotgun that does as much damage as a rocket launcher? Fight giant scorpions with chainguns, and 100-foot lava golems. And did I mention the headless kamikazes? This game is a SERIOUSLY fun time.

												There are a couple of reasons why this game was and still is a great one. First, even though it was not developed in a time where graphics were at their best, its makers really managed to pull out the best of what the graphic can be at that time. Second, it is a fun game and killing hordes and hordes of enemies and dicovering secrets never becomes boring with every level presenting a new challenge and a new way to overcome it. Last but not least, the producers of this game gave a lot of time and effort in designing every level, with the areas looking amazing and well detailed.However there is a single flaw in this game. It is a bit predictable.All in all, this game is a great game and one of my all time favourites.

												I have always enjoyed the Serious Sam games and they are a million times more amazing in HD. Originally I completed these games on the console and I was excited to find out that there was more content in the PC version. I highly recommend Serious Sam: First and Second Encounter, it's a satisfying Wave FPS with some comedy tossed in that gives the player a great feeling of progression and accomplishment on each playthrough. You can choose any levels already completed which is excellent for casual replay. Really this game is a classic for any library and if you haven't played it you are missing out.I believe the trick to enjoying the Serious Sam games is to set up keybindings for your weapons and learn them well as it will add alot of depth to gameplay.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Serious Sam, the character, is a time traveller sent back to ancient Egypt to fight aliens for reasons. Serious Sam, the game, feels more like it came from another dimension, a dimension where shooters never turns dust brown and clothed in ridiculous pretensions of militaristic realism. It is bright, colourful, imaginative and wilfully shallow and stupid.To my mind the most pleasantly surprising thing about Serious Sam is how simultaneously thoughtful and mindless it is. The mindlessness is obvious, you shoot all the aliens with the big guns. The thoughtfulness springs from varied nature of the enemies and weapons combined with how refreshingly fair and open the designers were about their scripting. The scripting is simple but brilliant. This is a game that will shamelessly spawn enemies directly in front of you if that is what the scripting calls for. This is game that doesn't give a damn about real world physical possibility so if it clashes with their level design then it can take a hike. On the other hand it also never appears to use infinite re-spawning of enemies. This allows for the player to play with the scripting, triggering a wave of enemies and then retreating slightly to deal with them before progressing. This might sound shoddy but it isn't, it really isn't, it is actually great because it allows the player to fully play the game rather than just experience it as a rollercoaster. This is a game that is made to be played rather than merely taken as some sort of an interactive cinematic experience. I won't spoil it but if you pay attention you'll notice the game even establishes an informal convention regarding some optional waves of enemies where the trigger can be identified and avoided by the play if they just want to continue.Honestly, this isn't the sort of game I love. I was never a fan of old school shooters. I like to sneak about and take things slowly rather than charging in all guns blazing and all guns blazing is Serious Sam's thing. I can't deny that this sort of thing has its place though and this is perhaps the best game I've played of this type of shooter. If you've just had a stressful week and just need something loud and stupid to comfort you then Serious Sam might be just the thing.

Posted: June 29, 2013
												If you like shooting a lot of things then this is the game for you.If you don't know, Serious Sam is a deliberate throwback to the old style of FPS games, like the original Doom and Quake.  Fast movement, blowing away tons of enemies, and maze-like levels are the norm here.This HD remake seems to be exactly the same game as regular Serious Sam The First Encounter, just obviously with increased model, texture, and animation quality on everything.  It is also running in an updated engine, but just playing through casually I dunno what benefits there are to that specifically.Anyway, I recommend, though maybe not at full price unless you really like old-school FPS games.

Posted: October 10, 2014
												I was late to the video game party. Never really getting into the idea of playing games to beat them until 2007 or so. And I never got into old school shooters. That is, until the year the HD version of Serious Sam: TFE came out. I happened to stumble across a youtube video and thought it looked interesting. Played the demo, thought it seemed cool. Payed the $15-$20 it cost and then came magic. This is in my top 5 FPS games of all time and one of my personal favourite video games. This game introduced me to the old school FPS genre and it easily made me more interested in First Person Shooters in general. The classic version is pretty much just as good, but a lot of effort was done in the remake and the HD version gets rid of that one little texture annoyance from the classics, where looking around really fast made everything distorted from 0.2 milliseconds. Not as good as Doom or Quake, but I am just as nostalgic for it as those games, if not even more so. Just buy it, right now. Don't think about it, just do. If you're worried about the difficulty, very easy is hard to die on and playing in classic co-op, you have infinite spawns. So theres nothing to be worried about. This is also a very good game to introduce you to the old school genre. I hadn't done much with old school FPS (aside from beating 1-2 levels in Doom) and I learned a lot of techniques from this game. I never strafed much in games before and after the first 3 levels of this game I was dodging stuff left and right. It isn't for everyone, but even if you just want a fun game to play through with a friend for a little distraction, it offers that. Although, I might reccomend SSHD:TSE over this one, if you just want a quick game you can marathon with a buddy and then forget about. I however, think it is a downright classic.AKA: BUY THIS GAME

												Pretty sure this has been the most fun I've had with buddies since early TF2, maybe even more so. The environments are a bit samey (Egypt, egypt and MORE EGYPT) but the same could be said of Quake and Doom (browns and reds in drab architecture everywhere). The big rushes are pure unadultered fun, with enemies coming in from every angle, really builds up your adrenaline even in single player. The weapons get more and more crazy as the game goes on, from the mundane (pump-action shotgun) to the insane (a handheld pirate's cannon, that you can charge up), they all serve a specific purpose and are useful even for the jobs they weren't meant for, yet all feel distinct.Buy it, play it with your friends, turn on teamkilling for added insanity.

Posted: March 7, 2015
												This is a game that you can only play with friends. That's not to say that it's a bad thing, on the contrary, it's a benefit. Serious Sam throws so much insanity, anger and general chaos at you that you're missing out if you don't have someone else to act as a human shield. Secrets are a lot easier to find, cooperation is fun and overall I'd say you should get it. Between the friendly fire, weapons and general adventure, it really is the more the merrier.There are some cons though:Boss battles that'll catch you off guard and don't always make sense initially. (Trust me on this.)Secrets can sometimes be unfairly hidden or require a great deal of work or searching to find.Enemies warp in, they don't have proper spawns or doors they walk through.No regenerating health. (Get good scrub, this ain't Call o' Duty.)There is a secret level that you will go the entire game without seeing. You might be able to guess where the entrance is, but it's going to take a while to get to it. If you're good, you won't cop out and look it up online. Yes, that means you.The last boss is just... insane. I won't spoil it for you, but you won't be ready for it.So, that being said, I'd say get the game. Great with friends. Unless you don't have friends, in which case find some you sad, lonely depressant.

Posted: March 9, 2015
												I have always enjoyed the Serious Sam games and they are a million times more amazing in HD. Originally I completed these games on the console and I was excited to find out that there was more content in the PC version. These versions are a lot of fun on Normal difficulty but becomes horrifyingly difficult on Hard. There are two more difficulty modes I would never attempt. I highly recommend Serious Sam: First and Second Encounter, it's a satisfying Wave FPS with some comedy tossed in that gives the player a great feeling of progression and accomplishment on each playthrough. You can choose any levels already completed which is excellent for casual replay. Really this game is a classic for any library and if you haven't played it you are missing out.I believe the trick to enjoying the Serious Sam games is to set up keybindings for your weapons and learn them well as it will add alot of depth to gameplay.

Posted: April 21
												Serious Sam is a game about killing as many enemies as possible before they overwhelm you. The game throws so many enemies at you at once, it's easy to become fatigued by the sheer amount. This game is intense. Hearing the galloping of hooves or the sound of the earth shaking while mooing sounds follow shortly after will scare you for life. The graphics look beautiful in the Serious Sam 3 engine. Killing monsters has never looked so amazing. The blood splattering on my face looked almost realistic. After I'd slaughtered everything, it was truly a treat to observe the scenery.  Sam loves to comment on events that take place sometimes. He doesn't comment on everything, just the new events that take place. Such as: encountering a new enemy for the first time.  Serious Sam: The First Encounter HD consists of one theme, 13 levels and two secret levels. The theme is Ancient Egypt. This game took me 7 hours to complete on normal difficulty. This is an old school shooter where the only goal is to get from A to B as you blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, without dying, while trying to find all the secrets. The story is simple and is given to by text as you advance through each level. You don't have to read the story, but I found it interesting even if it is basic. If you love Doom, you will love this game. The gameplay is very fun. However, the game does become repetitive after a while as the game does very little to mix things up. This game loves to trap you in tight corridors while spawning enemies around you. It does it quite often. It becomes very predictable. The game loves to trick you by placing traps around each level. To bait you, they love to activate them after you collect health and ammo. Do you see that heart over there? IT'S A TRAP! I did become bored after three hours of blowing up enemies as it all began to feel the same. I began to think: "Ok... I've been blowing up these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s for ages! When can I advance to find something new?"  The levels are very well designed. Nothing feels cluttered or wasted. Everything has been well placed and thought out. The enemies are incredibly varied. Each enemy is designed for a specific purpose. One enemy will sprint towards you, whilst another will bombard you with fire from above. But they were merely a distraction. Three more powerful enemies will charge through the weaker ones and strike you. There are 17 different enemies in this game. The sound is a bit iffy sometimes. It's subpar compared to everything else. It doesn't sound top notch. This makes it obvious that they didn't have a high budget when they were making this game. After all, they were on the verge of bankruptcy at the time. Serious Sam saved the studio. However, they could have remade them for the HD edition. There are ten weapons. Each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You will use all of them as ammo is fairly scarce. Especially when battling hordes of enemies. The mini gun and XL2 Lasergun feel very powerful to wield. I loved spraying bullets at the enemies as they charged towards me. It feels very nice. However, the Schofield .45 and the 12 Gauge Pump-Action Shotgun are useless after you pickup the Double Barrel Coach Gun and the M1A2 Thompson as there are simply too many enemies in the later levels for them to be useful. They're too weak.  There have been things removed from the HD remake of Serious Sam: The First Encounter due to issues regarding the engine. Such as: the inverted-gravity effect in The First Encounter has been removed and Harpies can no longer carry Beheaded Kamikazes. The online multiplayer has been improved, but unfortunately no one is online. Score-match has been removed. Presentation: 7/10 Graphics: 8/10 Sound: 7/10 Gameplay: 7/10 Multiplayer: DEAD. RIP. Final Verdict: 7/10 Overall, it is a good game. But, I recommend you get it on sale if you do chose to purchase it. Recommended to the people who love Doom, Wolfenstein, Painkiller, Quake, Bulletstorm, Shadow Warrior, SiN Gold, and Turok.

Posted: October 12, 2016
												Okay, so after finishing this game, I decided to first finish SS:HD - The Second Encounter before I reviewed either of them. Earlier today, I did just that, so now I feel I can deliver the verdict.The game was pretty short, but good. It's made in the same engine as Serious Sam 3, and shares many of it's (fantastic) visuals with that game, including the gorgeous blood. Now, when compared to SS:3, it was admittedly a tad sub-par, but that shouldn't surprise anyone considering the original SS:TFE was released so long ago, and SS:3 was made with newer stuff. But what if you don't compare it to SS:3?Wellm the game was good. The level-design and layout was surprisingly good, shocking even, considering the original levels were made more than a decade ago. The secrets were clever, as we've come to expect from Croteam. The weapons were very nicely remastered. The enemies were... dang, they were frustrating. These SS:HD enemies are really irritating at times. Aside from that, I don't really have any major criticisms for this game.So long story short:If you're a Serious Sam fan, get this. Especially if you've played the first Serious Sam game that this game remastered, and you're in the mood for some nostalgia. You're probably only going to play this first one once, but it's a good thing to have under your belt if you want to be considered a Serious Sam veteren, or if you're just looking for something fresh. SS:HD - The Second Encounter is actually very replayable, but I'll get to that one in my review for it.

												Serious Sam is a classic old school FPS with a fast and frenetic twist. The action in this game is extremely quick and can have you aiming, ducking, and dodging enemies from every angle with a slew of fun to use weapons (fans of games like Unreal Tournament will recognize this formula)The HD coat of paint is a nice touch, but the game still keeps it's classic 80's action hero vibe with challenging combat the higher the difficulty goes.Saving constantly is a must because most times the games won;t do it for you and enemies can be unforgiving.Challenging, but not impossible, it's a nostalgic blast to the past for me and well worth playing.

Posted: March 20, 2016
												Short Review: Serious sam is a great, fast pace, FPS that is even better in HDLong Review:STORY: The game puts you in the shoes of, well, Serious Sam. Saving the Earth of Ailens trying to take it over. And that's all the story you need, Sam is every single badass from the 80's rolled into one. Though not as ego induced as Duke Nukem, he still just as awesome. Every single one-liner will make you laugh (even out loud).GAMEPLAY: The gameplay of Serious Sam is like Duke Nukem 3D, see something, pump lead in it. But what makes Serious Sam differ from Duke Nukem is the enemies and how they work. In Serious Sam, enemies are more aggressive in nature and will come at you from every direction. While in Duke Nukem enemies stay in one place and wait for you to come. Serious Sam takes the FPS to the next level being tough as nails and it doesn't care if you're ready or not. It will throw everything at you. LEVELS: Levels are large and open, giving you more room to run around and avoid thousands of enemies. The most you'll see in TFE is deserts and some jungle areas, even though the visuals don't change the layoout does, Making every level feel different from one another.Overall I give Serious Sam a.... 9.8/10. Great levels, great gameplay, and a great main character. The only thing I would highly recommend is wait until the game's on sale. Because you can get TFE and TSE for only two dollars.

Posted: August 3, 2016
												I'm really tempted to put off writing this so I can hit that convienent "Play Now" button. I'll put it straight- Are you one of those folks who loves more traditional FPSes for all of their glorious superiorities over more modern ones? This is the game for you. No sprinting, no ironsights, no regenerating health, just you against waves of enemies with weapons that feel so good to shoot. Think how great it felt to use the shotgun in DooM, it's just like that. You know what I also really love about this game? Serious Engine 3 lets me play this game on settings close to ultra with framerates consistently around 60 per second... on my laptop. To give you an idea of how impressive that is, here's my specs-1366x768 60Hz PnP monitor2.3GHz AMD Quad-Core A10-4600M APU (HP lies, it's actually maxed at 1.9GHz)6GB DDR3 SDRAMAMD Radeon HD 7640G with 3060MB total graphics memoryTypically this rig starts to choke when I play HL2 on ultra settings. I've seen rigs with worse specs than that play it with no problem. The point is that Serious Engine 3 is extremely efficent. Now you can play an old-school-style FPS with beautiful graphics on your low-end machine. I wish I'd tried this out sooner. Looking forwards to buying SS3: BFE soon!

Posted: July 30, 2016
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mineANOTHER DISCLAIMER: Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter and Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter's reviews are more or less the same as the gameplay mechanics are basically the same in both games. So please think before commenting about the similarity in the reviews Serious Sam HD: The First Encounter is a game developed by Croteam and published by the wonderful peeps at Devolver Digital. The First Encounter is the first part of two parts, known as The First Enocunter and The Second Encounter. The first two games in the Serious Sam series have been faithfully recreated in HD with a brand new engine and shiner graphics while still retaining the original game (now known as Serious Sam Classic)The story follows Sam "Serious" Stone as he is employed to travel back to Ancient Egypt after aliens take over the world in the near distant future to put a stop to the invasion in the first place. As Serious Sam, you get to travel across old Egyptian ruins and fighting against creatures of all shapes and sizesThe gameplay is like that of old classic games, such as DOOM and Wolfenstein where you shoot enemies non-stop in huge arenas whilst getting keys, objects, health and ammoSince this is an HD remake, we expect the game to be nicer than the original and with that it manages. The game runs on Croteam's very own engine, Serious Engine 3 and I must say the graphics were really nice. The arenas are huge and sprawling, full of Egyptian sceneryThe music and sound effects are faithfully brought back from the original, so nothing new there. The sound effects are good but you can hear the difference in sound quality, sometimes poor to sub-par. Music too was the same, the music quality varied from poor to sub-par but this is understandableThe only thing that bugged me was the enemies, they were annoying to say the least. Always running towards, knocking down your health like there no tomorrow and Serious Sam runs so slow that even my late grandmother could run faster than him. The game doesn't feel as face paced as other arena shooter games I've playedSerious Sam HD: The First Encounter was a good first part into the introduction into the Serious Sam series and I cannot wait to play the second part of Serious Sam HD: The Second Encounter. If I had to recommend either the classic versions or the HD remakes, I would go for the HD remakes. Although I would still recommend the classic versions of Serious Sam, I think the HD remakes still hold up RECOMMENDED :)

												A real surprise package to me to be honest. I'm not a serious Sam veteran and played it for the first time when it was recently in a ludicrous Steam sale. It truly encapsulates the shooters from the 90's in its frantic, fast over the top action. It doesn't really try to do anything new, in fact it does everything old but that's one of the things that makes it great. Its good manic fun and to me is everything that's good about the FPS genre, I mean, who needs cover when you have a mini gun?

Posted: October 12, 2016
												Okay, so after finishing this game, I decided to first finish SS:HD - The Second Encounter before I reviewed either of them. Earlier today, I did just that, so now I feel I can deliver the verdict.The game was pretty short, but good. It's made in the same engine as Serious Sam 3, and shares many of it's (fantastic) visuals with that game, including the gorgeous blood. Now, when compared to SS:3, it was admittedly a tad sub-par, but that shouldn't surprise anyone considering the original SS:TFE was released so long ago, and SS:3 was made with newer stuff. But what if you don't compare it to SS:3?Wellm the game was good. The level-design and layout was surprisingly good, shocking even, considering the original levels were made more than a decade ago. The secrets were clever, as we've come to expect from Croteam. The weapons were very nicely remastered. The enemies were... dang, they were frustrating. These SS:HD enemies are really irritating at times. Aside from that, I don't really have any major criticisms for this game.So long story short:If you're a Serious Sam fan, get this. Especially if you've played the first Serious Sam game that this game remastered, and you're in the mood for some nostalgia. You're probably only going to play this first one once, but it's a good thing to have under your belt if you want to be considered a Serious Sam veteren, or if you're just looking for something fresh. SS:HD - The Second Encounter is actually very replayable, but I'll get to that one in my review for it.

Posted: December 19, 2013
												Serious Sam, the character, is a time traveller sent back to ancient Egypt to fight aliens for reasons. Serious Sam, the game, feels more like it came from another dimension, a dimension where shooters never turns dust brown and clothed in ridiculous pretensions of militaristic realism. It is bright, colourful, imaginative and wilfully shallow and stupid.To my mind the most pleasantly surprising thing about Serious Sam is how simultaneously thoughtful and mindless it is. The mindlessness is obvious, you shoot all the aliens with the big guns. The thoughtfulness springs from varied nature of the enemies and weapons combined with how refreshingly fair and open the designers were about their scripting. The scripting is simple but brilliant. This is a game that will shamelessly spawn enemies directly in front of you if that is what the scripting calls for. This is game that doesn't give a damn about real world physical possibility so if it clashes with their level design then it can take a hike. On the other hand it also never appears to use infinite re-spawning of enemies. This allows for the player to play with the scripting, triggering a wave of enemies and then retreating slightly to deal with them before progressing. This might sound shoddy but it isn't, it really isn't, it is actually great because it allows the player to fully play the game rather than just experience it as a rollercoaster. This is a game that is made to be played rather than merely taken as some sort of an interactive cinematic experience. I won't spoil it but if you pay attention you'll notice the game even establishes an informal convention regarding some optional waves of enemies where the trigger can be identified and avoided by the play if they just want to continue.Honestly, this isn't the sort of game I love. I was never a fan of old school shooters. I like to sneak about and take things slowly rather than charging in all guns blazing and all guns blazing is Serious Sam's thing. I can't deny that this sort of thing has its place though and this is perhaps the best game I've played of this type of shooter. If you've just had a stressful week and just need something loud and stupid to comfort you then Serious Sam might be just the thing.

Posted: June 29, 2013
												If you like shooting a lot of things then this is the game for you.If you don't know, Serious Sam is a deliberate throwback to the old style of FPS games, like the original Doom and Quake.  Fast movement, blowing away tons of enemies, and maze-like levels are the norm here.This HD remake seems to be exactly the same game as regular Serious Sam The First Encounter, just obviously with increased model, texture, and animation quality on everything.  It is also running in an updated engine, but just playing through casually I dunno what benefits there are to that specifically.Anyway, I recommend, though maybe not at full price unless you really like old-school FPS games.

Saving the Earth of Ailens trying to take it over. And that's all the story you need, Sam is every single badass from the 80's rolled into one. Though not as ego induced as Duke Nukem, he still just as awesome. Every single one-liner will make you laugh (even out loud).GAMEPLAY: The gameplay of Serious Sam is like Duke Nukem 3D, see something, pump lead in it. But what makes Serious Sam differ from Duke Nukem is the enemies and how they work. In Serious Sam, enemies are more aggressive in nature and will come at you from every direction. While in Duke Nukem enemies stay in one place and wait for you to come. Serious Sam takes the FPS to the next level being tough as nails and it doesn't care if you're ready or not. It will throw everything at you. LEVELS: Levels are large and open, giving you more room to run around and avoid thousands of enemies. The most you'll see in TFE is deserts and some jungle areas, even though the visuals don't change the layoout does, Making every level feel different from one another.Overall I give Serious Sam a.... 9.8/10. Great levels, great gameplay, and a great main character. The only thing I would highly recommend is wait until the game's on sale. Because you can get TFE and TSE for only two dollars.

Posted: April 3
												This game can be described in 3 words: "Its a trap!!!"Its a game based around killing hordes and hordes of enemiesYou see a nice shiny pickup item in the distance. Go to it and boom you're surrounded. Monsters everywhere.But the game gives you the tools to kill these monsters. You have alot of weapons at your disposal. There are alot of ammo and health to pickup.The game autosaves for you. You wont even need to quicksave. You have multiple saves, dont have to worry about a save getting overwritten.The First Encounter takes place in Ancient Egypt so the levels are Egyptian themed.This is not a covershooter. You cant hide and regenerate your health (unless you're playing on "Tourist Difficulty" ). You need to keep moving, shooting and dodging.There are also secrets to find.There are 2 or 3 instances where the game might go overboard with a horde and it overstays its welcome. And you wish it would stop because its a tedious horde.Switching weapons can feel a bit slow in the heat of battle.Not enough gore. Enemy corpses vanish. After a crazy battle the area is way too clean. There needs to be blood and guts everywhere.Arachnoid have hitscan weapons.The Second Encounter has everything The First Encounter has and more.TFE levels can even be played in TSE if you own both games.There are new enemies.New weapons: flamethrower, chainsaw, sniper rifle, bomb.

Posted: January 6
												If you just wanna know if I would recommend this game... YES! But if you wanna see my detailed opinion about this glorious painkiller, then continue reading.I am a fan of FPS games, I have played through Wolfenstein to Overwatch, and I have to say THIS type of first person shooters are my favorite. Just games where you kill, kill and kill, without any compromising story, best graphics ever, but with a kickass soundtrack, stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥and just doing some massacres. This game just wants you to feel powerful, and that is what you will get here with many guns and enemies, the maps are fun but linear, but for me this is not a problem for games that are in this category. The length of this game is... ok, the levels take a little too long for my likings but its only 15 levels, you will probably end this game in 9-12 hours, nothing very special. Now, is this game in HD worth it? of course it is, from what i have seen this HD version just makes graphics better, and in my opinion I think its more worth buying this HD version than the original, just 15 bucks.The soundtrack is ok for this game but it would have been much much better, and as I said, the story is ♥♥♥♥ing generic, something that in this genre I wouldn't mind having a♥♥♥♥♥♥story. And the multiplayer is fun, not the best but it can give you some good moments with your friends, BUT, if you wanna buy this game just for the multiplayer, DONT!, simply because its not worth the 15 dollars just for that and its not the main spectacular thing of this game, and if you dont have friends who own this game, you wont find matches online either.So in conclusion, I think this could be a good 1st try of this type of games, and in my opinion its one of the best FPSs ever, it doesn't add nothing new to the genre but still is plenty of fun, if you like and finish this game, I would recommend you to buy the HD version of Serious Sam 2, simply because its also as same as fun as this one.My rating to this game is a 8.8/10

Posted: February 28
												The best game in the core series.The sequel went from 9th generation of FPS (sawtoothed arenas with spawning enemies) to being an action game. But together with new and diverse level sets it only made game less of a repetitive grindfest (FE). Also new story and direction finally tied that whole mishmash pile of enemies into cohesive world in that rare setting of cartoony zany vinegret (like alice in wonderland, or Heavy Metal: F.A.K.K.² in this case). And unlike BFE it doesn't turn them into a grey-brown color-corrected unremarkable dullness.Story is a generic post-modernistic referential "deconstruction" with extremely dumb jokes which are delivered rather well and usually funny. But while having good enough mechanical catharsis with the last boss, plot-wise it just tells that main antagonist got away, ((( I R O N I C A L L Y ))) point its finger on it and says "OH YOU GUISE AIN'T THIS DUMB, AIN'T ME SO HIP AND COOL TO POINT AT IT?".Still, technically it is a 9th generation FPS in it's core gameplay and is mostly the same as first games, just with turrets, vehicular sections and overload of cutscenes (and loading times between them). It mostly behaves as expected and some guns are rebalanced to be more pleasant and useful. Also this game has one of the best shotguns (which is also totally balanced) i can remember (first place being taken by Ex Machina shotguns, which are that way only by happy coincidence of several minor bugs, though).Well, hope you liked bulls and kreels from the original, because those types of enemies make about 50% of them all, even some old ones have this new behaviour. The other 50% are annoying flying monsters; everywhere. It kinda gets overboard on the latter levels, but is still manageable.When it was released i didn't like the new face of sam, but now i think it's kinda better that way — it has the most character and is most recognizable. BFE sam is also beats the original version. Most music is kinda great, but totally ruined with dynamic mixing.Technically game is mostly fine, it works In UHD UWS Surround after editing of .ini file and runs stable. But sometimes mouse behaves strange and feels off or laggy and game sometimes can corrupt your save file so it would crash the game on read or write, so better have bunch of them and do it often.

Posted: April 21
												Serious Sam is a game about killing as many enemies as possible before they overwhelm you. The game throws so many enemies at you at once, it's easy to become fatigued by the sheer amount. This game is intense. Hearing the galloping of hooves or the sound of the earth shaking while mooing sounds follow shortly after will scare you for life. The graphics look beautiful in the Serious Sam 3 engine. Killing monsters has never looked so amazing. The blood splattering on my face looked almost realistic. After I'd slaughtered everything, it was truly a treat to observe the scenery.  Sam loves to comment on events that take place sometimes. He doesn't comment on everything, just the new events that take place. Such as: encountering a new enemy for the first time.  Serious Sam: The First Encounter HD consists of one theme, 13 levels and two secret levels. The theme is Ancient Egypt. This game took me 7 hours to complete on normal difficulty. This is an old school shooter where the only goal is to get from A to B as you blow♥♥♥♥♥♥up, without dying, while trying to find all the secrets. The story is simple and is given to by text as you advance through each level. You don't have to read the story, but I found it interesting even if it is basic. If you love Doom, you will love this game. The gameplay is very fun. However, the game does become repetitive after a while as the game does very little to mix things up. This game loves to trap you in tight corridors while spawning enemies around you. It does it quite often. It becomes very predictable. The game loves to trick you by placing traps around each level. To bait you, they love to activate them after you collect health and ammo. Do you see that heart over there? IT'S A TRAP! I did become bored after three hours of blowing up enemies as it all began to feel the same. I began to think: "Ok... I've been blowing up these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s for ages! When can I advance to find something new?"  The levels are very well designed. Nothing feels cluttered or wasted. Everything has been well placed and thought out. The enemies are incredibly varied. Each enemy is designed for a specific purpose. One enemy will sprint towards you, whilst another will bombard you with fire from above. But they were merely a distraction. Three more powerful enemies will charge through the weaker ones and strike you. There are 17 different enemies in this game. The sound is a bit iffy sometimes. It's subpar compared to everything else. It doesn't sound top notch. This makes it obvious that they didn't have a high budget when they were making this game. After all, they were on the verge of bankruptcy at the time. Serious Sam saved the studio. However, they could have remade them for the HD edition. There are ten weapons. Each with their own strengths and weaknesses. You will use all of them as ammo is fairly scarce. Especially when battling hordes of enemies. The mini gun and XL2 Lasergun feel very powerful to wield. I loved spraying bullets at the enemies as they charged towards me. It feels very nice. However, the Schofield .45 and the 12 Gauge Pump-Action Shotgun are useless after you pickup the Double Barrel Coach Gun and the M1A2 Thompson as there are simply too many enemies in the later levels for them to be useful. They're too weak.  There have been things removed from the HD remake of Serious Sam: The First Encounter due to issues regarding the engine. Such as: the inverted-gravity effect in The First Encounter has been removed and Harpies can no longer carry Beheaded Kamikazes. The online multiplayer has been improved, but unfortunately no one is online. Score-match has been removed. Presentation: 7/10 Graphics: 8/10 Sound: 7/10 Gameplay: 7/10 Multiplayer: DEAD. RIP. Final Verdict: 7/10 Overall, it is a good game. But, I recommend you get it on sale if you do chose to purchase it. Recommended to the people who love Doom, Wolfenstein, Painkiller, Quake, Bulletstorm, Shadow Warrior, SiN Gold, and Turok.

Posted: March 4
												Great game. Simple FPS game with great storyline and punchlines.
